Re-inspection fees shall be required in accordance with the fee schedule as adopted by the governing authority when work performed is required to be re-inspected due to the following reasons: (1) The re-inspection is not approved due to a failure to correct a previously noted code violation on a prior inspection; (2) The job is not ready for inspection when an inspection is requested and performed; (3) The building or structure is not accessible and inspection cannot be performed; (4) Work to be inspected has been covered or concealed and proper inspection cannot be performed; or (5) Prior issuance of a stop work order requires re-inspection. (m) Right of entry. Inspections required under the provisions of this chapter shall be made by the building official or designee. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the building official or designee may enter the premises between 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. to perform any duty imposed by this chapter provided that the building official or designee has consent to enter the premises or has obtained and presents an inspection warrant as described in this chapter. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.12), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-16. - Certificates of occupancy, tenancy. (a) Required. No building or structure or portion thereof shall be occupied or a change made in the type of occupancy or the nature of the use of an existing building or part thereof until after an appropriate certificate as required by this section has been issued. (b) Certificate of occupancy. (1) Issuance. A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued by the building official until the building, structure and intended use complies with all applicable requirements of the zoning ordinance, all construction is complete and all required final building, plumbing, mechanical, gas, electric, fire, health, vegetation protection and site drainage inspections have been performed and approved. (2) Scope. The certificate of occupancy certifies that all final inspections have been completed and the structure has been erected, to the best of the city's knowledge, in compliance with applicable Code requirements at the time of the issuance of the certificate. However, issuance of a certificate of occupancy shall not excuse the builder, contractor, tenant, or property owner from liability for any violation of the Code or any other applicable laws. Occupancy shall be limited to the area or portion of a building or structure defined by the building permit for which the certificate of occupancy is issued. (c) Temporary certificate of occupancy. (1) Scope. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for non-residential buildings or portions thereof for a specified period of time when it has been determined by the building official or designee that no outstanding Code violations or deficiencies exist and the building may be safely occupied for the use and time requested. A request for a temporary certificate of occupancy shall be made on such form as prescribed by the building official, which will include specific times and dates for temporary use and shall be signed by the owner/occupant, contractor and or agent. (2) Issuance. A temporary certificate of occupancy shall be issued for stated purposes only when construction has not been fully completed and all final inspections have not been performed. Provided the owner should be aware that in certain circumstances payment and performance bonds may be required as a condition for a temporary certificate of occupancy. (3) Revocation. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be revoked at the option of the building official for any and/or all of the following reasons: a. Violation of any building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical, fire safety or site development codes or regulations. b. Failure to complete any stage of construction and/or site improvements required by the building official in a timely manner. c. Unauthorized occupancy or use of any part or portion of the building or structure other than the area or portion for which a temporary certificate of occupancy has been granted. d. Any other conditions that may affect the health, safety and welfare of persons or property. (d) Certificate of completion. A certificate of completion shall be issued upon satisfactory completion of a building, structure, and/or plumbing, mechanical, gas or electrical system, when a certificate of occupancy is not required. The certificate of completion does not grant authority to occupy a building or structure or change the type of occupancy or nature of use prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (e) Certificate of change of tenant. (1) Scope. A certificate of change of tenant shall be required whenever there is a change of tenant occupancy in any non-residential building, structure or use and no construction, alterations, improvements or repairs to the building, structure, plumbing, mechanical, gas or electrical systems have been or are to be made. The new tenant or building owner shall be required to submit current as-built floor and fixture plans for review and complete a repair/improvement declaration. (2) Permits required. If the change of tenant involves any construction, alterations, improvements or repairs to the building, plumbing, mechanical, gas or electrical systems, all necessary permits required by this chapter shall be obtained by licensed qualified contractors and all necessary inspections shall be performed by the building official before a change of tenant, or if required, a new certificate of occupancy is issued. (f) Contents of certificates. Certificates shall contain the following: (1) The building permit number (or in the case of a certificate of completion, the appropriate trade permit number). (2) The address of the structure. (3) The name and address of the owner. (4) A description of that portion of the structure for which the certificate is issued. (5) A statement that the described portion of the structure has been inspected for compliance with the requirements of this chapter. (6) The name of the building official and fire marshal. (7) The edition of the code under which the permit was issued. (8) If non-residential, the use and occupancy, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 3 of the International Building Code. (9) If non-residential, the type of construction as defined in Chapter 6 of the International Building Code. (10) If non-residential, the design occupant load. (11) If an automatic sprinkler is provided, whether the sprinkler system is required. (12) Any special stipulations and conditions of the building permit. (g) Revocation of certificates. The building official or designee may revoke certificates of occupancy, certificates of completion, and certificates of change of tenant issued under provisions of this chapter, where it is shown that there have been either one or more of the following: (1) Changes or alterations in construction, type of permitted use or occupancy without written approval by the building official or designee. (2) Changes or violations of the conditions of the certificate without written approval by the building official or designee. (3) Alterations, additions, or improvements to the building, structure, or systems without permits and inspections required by this chapter. (4) Violation of any zoning, building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical, fire safety or site development codes or regulations. (5) Any condition that may affect the building, structure or service system which, in the opinion of the director of planning and development services, renders the building, structure or service system unsafe, dangerous or uninhabitable. (6) After a certificate has been revoked, a valid certificate shall not be issued until all violations, changes, alterations, additions or improvements meet all requirements of this chapter as determined by the building official. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.13), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-17. - Utility service connections. (a) Connection of service utilities. No person shall make connections from a utility, source of energy, fuel or power to any building or system that is regulated by this chapter for which a permit is required, until approved by the building official. (b) Permanent electrical service connection. Permanent electrical service connection and meter shall not be authorized until all required final building, plumbing, mechanical, gas, electrical, drainage, vegetation, fire and health inspections have been performed and approved by the appropriate city or state department or official. (c) Permanent gas service connection. Permanent gas service connection and meter shall not be authorized until the gas supply house line has been tested, inspected and approved and all appliance and equipment connections have been inspected and approved. (d) Temporary electrical and gas service connections. Temporary electrical and gas service and meter connections may be authorized for a specified period of time when the system has been inspected and found to be safe for the connections and use authorized. Such temporary service connections shall be authorized only for the following reasons: (1) Testing of appliances and equipment. (2) Temporary occupancy of the building or structure only for the training of employees or stocking of merchandise. (3) Single-tenant occupancy buildings and multi-tenant occupancy buildings for which temporary service connections have been authorized shall not be allowed access by the general public for business activity other than those allowed in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. (e) Authority to disconnect utility services. The building official shall have the authority to authorize disconnection of utility service to the building, structure or system regulated by this chapter in case of an emergency, where necessary, to eliminate an immediate danger to life or property. Where possible, the owner and occupant of the building, structure or service system shall be notified of the decision to disconnect utility service prior to taking such action. If not notified prior to disconnecting, the owner or occupant of the building, structure or service system shall be notified in writing, as soon as practical thereafter. (f) Connection after order to disconnect. No person shall make connections from any energy, fuel, power supply or water distribution system or supply energy, fuel or water to any equipment regulated by this chapter that has been disconnected or ordered to be disconnected by the building official or the use of which has been ordered to be discontinued by the building official until the building official authorizes the reconnection and use of such equipment. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.14), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-18. - Violations, remedies and penalties. (a) Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, move, remove, demolish or occupy any building, structure, system or equipment regulated by this chapter, or cause same to be done, in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or other applicable provisions of this Code. (b) Notice of violation. The building official is authorized to serve a notice of violation or order on the person responsible for the erection, construction, alteration, extension, repair, moving, removing, demolition, or occupancy of a building or structure, system or equipment in violation of the provisions of this chapter, or in violation of a permit or certificate of occupancy under the provisions of this chapter. Such notice or order shall direct the discontinuance or correction of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. (c) Penalties. Any person failing to discontinue, correct or abate the violation of this chapter as ordered by the building official in the notice shall be subject to issuance of a court citation to appear in the City of Albany, Georgia Municipal Court to answer a charge of violations of this chapter and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine and/or imprisonment in accordance to section 1-17. Where any offense continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.15), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-19. - Stop work order. (a) Authority. Whenever the building official finds any work regulated by this chapter being performed in a manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, the building official is authorized to issue a stop work order. (b) Issuance. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. Upon issuance of a stop work order, the cited work shall immediately cease. The stop work order shall state the reason for the order, and the conditions under which the cited work will be permitted to resume. (c) Unlawful continuance. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to correct a violation or an unsafe condition, shall be subject to issuance of a court citation to appear in the municipal court of the City of Albany, Georgia and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine and/or imprisonment in accordance with section 1-17. Where any offense continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.16), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-20. - Inspection warrants. (a) The building official, in addition to other procedures provided by law, may obtain an inspection warrant under the conditions specified in this section. The warrant shall authorize the building official to conduct a search or inspection of property without the consent of the person whose property is to be searched or inspected, under the conditions set out in this section. (b) Inspection warrants may be issued by any judge of the recorder's court when the issuing judge is satisfied that all of the following conditions are met: (1) The person seeking the warrant must establish under oath or affirmation that the property to be inspected is to be inspected as a part of a legally authorized program of inspection which includes that property, or that there is probable cause for believing that there is a condition, object, activity, or circumstance which legally justifies such an inspection of that property; (2) The issuing judge determines that the issuance of the warrant is authorized by this division and all other applicable law; (3) The warrant is attached to the affidavit required to be made in order to obtain the warrant; (4) The warrant describes, either directly or by reference to the affidavit, the property upon which the inspection is to occur and is sufficiently accurate that the executor of the warrant and the owner or possessor of the property can reasonably determine from it the property for which the warrant authorizes a search or inspection; (5) The warrant indicates the conditions, objects, activities, or circumstances which the search or inspection is intended to check or reveal; and (6) The warrant refers, in general terms, to the provisions of the Code or state law sought to be enforced. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.17), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-21. - Unsafe conditions. (a) Conditions. Structures or existing equipment that are or hereafter become unsafe, uninhabitable, or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, shall be deemed an unsafe condition. Structures that are deemed an unsafe condition shall be taken down and removed or rehabilitated pursuant to city Ordinance 06-103. (b) Notice. If an unsafe condition is found, the building official shall serve on the owner, agent or person in control of the building, structure or system found to be unsafe, a written notice that describes the condition deemed unsafe and specifies the required repairs or improvements to be made to abate the unsafe condition, or that requires the unsafe structure to be demolished within a stipulated time. Such notice shall require the person thus notified to declare immediately to the building official written acceptance or rejection of the terms of the notice. (c) Method of service. Such notice shall be deemed properly served if a copy thereof is (a) delivered to the owner personally; (b) sent by certified or registered mail addressed to the owner at the owner's last known address with the return receipt requested. If the certified or registered letter is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place on or about the building or structure affected by such notice. Service of such notice in the foregoing manner upon the owner's agent or upon the person responsible for the building or structure shall constitute service of notice upon the owner. (d) Restoration. The building, structure, system or equipment determined to be unsafe by the building official is permitted to be restored to a safe condition. To the extent that repairs, alterations, or additions are made or a change of occupancy occurs during the restoration of the building, structure, system or equipment, such repairs, alterations or additions or change of occupancy shall comply with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.18), 1-12-2009) Sec. 14-22. - Technical codes adopted. (a) Generally. As future new editions and/or amendments of the codes listed below are adopted by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, they shall become a part of or replacement for the adopted codes, rules and regulations or standards and shall become enforceable as prescribed without separate adoption by the governing authority. All new construction, installations, repairs or alterations shall be in conformance with the current edition of the following codes and referenced appendixes with Georgia amendments as currently adopted by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs: (1) International Building Code with Georgia Amendments. (2) International Residential Code with Georgia Amendments. (3) International Plumbing Code with Georgia Amendments. (4) International Mechanical Code with Georgia Amendments. (5) International Fuel Gas Code with Georgia Amendments. (6) National Electrical Code with Georgia Amendments. (7) International Energy Conservation Code with Georgia Amendments. (8) International Fire Code with Georgia Amendments. (9) International Property Maintenance Code with Georgia Amendments. (b) Referenced standards. Standards referenced in the above-stated codes shall be considered an integral part of the code without separate adoption. If specific portions of a standard are denoted by a code test, only those portions of the standard shall be enforced. Where code provisions conflict with a standard, the code provisions shall be govern. Permissive and advisory provisions in a standard shall not be construed as mandatory. (c) Appendices. The appendices included in any code adopted pursuant to this chapter are not intended for enforcement unless specifically referenced in this chapter or specifically included in this Code. (d) Referenced codes and standards. The adopted state codes adopted pursuant to this division shall be considered part of the requirements of this chapter to the prescribed extent of each such adoption. Where differences occur between the provisions of this chapter and referenced codes and standards, the provisions of this chapter shall govern. Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the state adopted International Residential Code. (1) A set of plans that include building, plumbing, mechanical, and electrical plans and the site plan as required in section 14-10(a) shall be maintained on the construction site at all times. (2) A site plan or staking survey prepared and sealed by a registered engineer or land surveyor shall be submitted at the time of the residential footing or slab inspection and prior to the pouring of same. Survey shall show the setbacks from all property lines. Setbacks shall comply with all minimum zoning ordinance requirements and/or legally acquired variances. (Ord. No. 09-101, § 4(8-3.19), 1-12-2009; Ord. No. 09-109, § 3, 2-24-2009) Sec. 14-23. - The state energy code adopted. The Georgia State Minimum Standard Energy Code, is hereby adopted, as supplemented and amended by the state department of community affairs, and enforcement of said code is directed in accordance with state law. (Code 1985, § 8-4; Ord. No. 91-113, § 1, 2-12-1991) Sec. 14-24. - Self inspection. O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26, relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, shall not be applicable within the city. (Code 1985, § 8-5; Ord. No. 96-270, § 1, 6-25-1996) Sec. 14-25. - Performance and payment bond for projects over $100,000.00. A performance and payment bond in the amount of the total amount payable by the terms of the contract is required for any housing rehabilitation or new housing construction project when the contract exceeds $100.000.00. (Code 1985, § 8-6; Ord. No. 98-136, § 1, 7-14-1998) Sec. 14-26. - Amendments. The following shall be considered amendments, additions to, changes in or exceptions to section 14-1(9): (1) Replace all references of the ICC Electrical Code to the National Electrical Code (NEC). (2) Replace all references to the International Zoning Code to the Zoning Ordinance of the city and Dougherty County, Georgia. (3) Delete sections 103.1, 103.2, 103.3, 103.5, 108.2, 109.6, 111, 302.4, 302.8, 302.9, 304.3, 307.2 through 307.3.2. (4) Section 101.1. City of Albany, Georgia. (5) Section 104.1. Whenever the term "code official" appears in the International property Maintenance Code it shall be construed to mean the code enforcement department director or the code enforcement department director's designee. (6) Section 107.2(5) is modified to state "inform the property owner that failure to abate the violation shall result in a summons issued to appear in municipal court. (7) Section 304.14. Insert: 1st day of January to the 31st day of December. (8) Add Exception to section 308.3: Extermination of wood destroying organisms shall, in all cases, be the responsibility of the building owner. (9) Sections 602.3 and 602.4. Insert: 1st day of September to the 31st day of May. (Ord. No. 08-118, § 3(8-40), 6-25-2008)

div.head: Chapter 16 - BUSINESSES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 16-1. - Exemption from license fee and occupation tax. The following persons, firms, companies, or corporations engaged in any trade, business, profession or occupation in the city are exempt from the requirement of paying an occupation tax: (1) Each person operating a business in the city under a veteran's certificate of exemption issued by the state, department of veteran's service. (2) Any nonprofit organization conducting business activities directly related to its nonprofit status within the city. A nonprofit organization is defined as an organization which is classified as nonprofit by the Internal Revenue Service and exempt from federal tax under Internal Revenue Service regulations. A nonprofit organization doing business that is not directly related to their nonprofit status will be required to obtain an occupation tax certificate and pay an occupation tax for every business activity conducted that is not directly related to their nonprofit status. (3) Businesses subject to a franchise fee. Any person, firm, company, or corporation engaged in any trade, business, profession or occupation in the city which is subject to payment of a franchise fee under state law or city ordinance shall not be subject to pay an occupation tax. All exempt organizations are required to file an application and obtain an occupation tax certificate under the applicable regulations as promulgated by the finance director or the finance director's designee. All exempt organizations will be subject to the same requirements of businesses obtaining occupation tax certificates, although exempt organizations will not be subject to occupation taxes. (Code 1985, § 26-30; Ord. No. 95-152, § 5, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001) Sec. 16-2. - Finance director or designee; power and authority. The finance director or the finance director's designee shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article, or other ordinances, of the city and laws of the state or the Constitution of this state or of the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the occupation taxes. (Code 1985, § 26-35.6; Ord. No. 95-152, § 16, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001) Sec. 16-3. - Reciprocity policy concerning vendors and suppliers. (1) A vendor or supplier who is resident within the municipal limits of the city or the unincorporated area of the county and which holds a current occupation tax certificate issued by the city or the county shall be granted the same preference over vendors resident in another city or county or state in the same manner, on the same basis and to the same extent that preference is granted in awarding bids for the same goods or services by such other city, county or state to vendors resident therein over vendors resident in the city or the county, if such preference is made known prior to the award of a bid. (2) This section requires that a local vendor or supplier seeking to invoke the benefits of the city's reciprocity policy match the price of the foreign vendor or supplier. (Ord. No. 09-116, § 1, 3-24-2009; Ord. No. 11-116, §§ 1, 2, 8-23-2011) Sec. 16-4. - Local procurement preference. (a) Application of local procurement preference. The local preference shall be available only to a supplier or vendor who, at the date of the purchase or bid for supplies acquired under this policy, and for a period of at least 90 days prior thereto, maintains and has maintained an office and place of business physically located within Dougherty County, Georgia, who has at least two full time employees working at or out of said office and business location, and who holds a current City of Albany or Dougherty County Occupational Tax Certificate. Post office boxes shall not be used for the purpose of establishing said physical address. No preference will be available where the supplier/vendor fails to make such a written request. (b) Local procurement preference. There is hereby established the following local procurement preference in purchasing. In any case where purchases made pursuant to this policy are made under the provisions permitting purchase without obtaining bids or competitive quotations, such purchases shall be made from a Dougherty County supplier, where available. Where purchases are made by obtaining competitive quotations, or by a bidding process, whenever a supplier who meets the qualifications in subsection (a) above submits a quotation or a bid that is responsive and is within five percent of the lowest responsive bid or quote, such supplier shall be afforded the opportunity to match the bid or quote. Should such supplier agree to match the lowest responsible bid or quote, then the purchase shall be made from such supplier, provided such supplier is otherwise qualified. (c) Exceptions. The preference contained in this section shall not apply to the following purchases: (1) Good or services provided under a cooperative purchasing agreement or interlocal agreement; (2) Contracts for professional services procurement of which is subject to any competitive consultant selection policy or procedure adopted or utilized by the city commission; (3) Purchases or contracts which are funded, in whole or in part, by a governmental entity and the laws, regulations, or policies governing such funding prohibit application of that preference; (4) Purchases made or contracts let under emergency situations. (d) In order to take advantage of the local preference, a supplier's/vendor's ad valorem taxes on real and personal property in Albany/Dougherty County cannot be delinquent. (e) The mayor and board of commissioners understand that city staff will monitor the effectiveness of the preference and prepare at least an annual report, beginning May 28, 2014, and each anniversary thereafter. (Ord. No. 13-115, §§ 1—3, 5-28-2013; Ord. No. 15-102, § 1, 1-27-2015) Editor's note— Section 6 of Ord. No. 13-115, states, "Unless an ordinance is enacted within three (3) years of this date that extends this Ordinance, this Ordinance shall terminate in three (3) years." Secs. 16-5—16-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS
Sec. 16-23. - Occupation tax certificate. (a) It is unlawful and punishable for any person, firm, company or corporation to engage in any business, trade, profession or occupation in the City of Albany, Georgia, without obtaining an occupation tax certificate, unless exempted. (b) Each incident of doing business without such occupation tax certificate shall be an offense punishable as provided in sections 1-17 and 1-18. (Code 1985, § 17-8; Ord. No. 94-150, §§ 1, 2, 8-9-1994) Sec. 16-24. - Duty to obtain; exception. In addition to registering with the city finance director and paying the tax as required, it shall be the duty of every person before engaging or offering to engage in any business, trade, profession within the city, for which an occupation tax or fee is charged or assessed, to first apply to and obtain from the city finance director an occupation tax certificate. (Code 1975, § 14-2; Code 1985, § 26-17) Sec. 16-25. - Occupations, professions, business exempt from licensing. Those occupations, professions and businesses as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16 shall be exempt from the regulations of this article. (Code 1975, § 27-62; Code 1985, § 26-18) State Law reference— Occupations, businesses and practitioners exempt from occupation tax, regulatory fees, and registration fees, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16. Sec. 16-26. - Issuance of special permits. Where this Code or the ordinances of the city require a special permit from the board of city commissioners to engage in any business, it shall be the duty of the city finance director to see that such permit has been granted before any license is issued. (Code 1975, § 14-3; Code 1985, § 26-19) Sec. 16-27. - Form. All licenses issued by authority of the city shall be in such form as the board of city commissioners may from time to time prescribe. (Code 1975, § 14-4; Code 1985, § 26-20) Sec. 16-28. - Posting. It shall be the duty of every person to post and keep posted, in a conspicuous place, at or in their place of business, their occupational license. (Code 1975, § 14-5; Code 1985, § 26-21) Sec. 16-29. - Assignment or transfer. No license issued by the city shall be transferable or assignable, but shall be personal to the person to whom issued; provided, however, that all licenses, except those for which a special permit is required, when issued to a person shall, upon such person selling out in toto to another person, intending to continue such business, remain of full force and effect for the full term for which issued, but relative to the business excepted in this article, the license for same, either on selling out or upon any change in business, either by taking on new owners or members with the person or firm, or on taking on new stockholders of a corporation, shall be forfeited immediately upon such change. (Code 1975, § 14-6; Code 1985, § 26-22) Sec. 16-30. - Records. The city finance director shall keep a detailed record of all licenses issued by him or her, showing the date and to whom issued and such other data as the finance director deems proper for an identification of the original. (Code 1975, § 14-7; Code 1985, § 26-23) Sec. 16-31. - Forfeiture; proceedings; causes; etc. Where there is no provision made, the violation of which operates to forfeit a license and the board of city commissioners or any citizen desires, for any reason, to have any particular license forfeited, the board of city commissioners, on written complaint of any member or of any citizen, setting forth the cause of complaint fully, shall order the licensee to show cause why his or her license should not be forfeited. Such order shall be signed by the city finance director and bear test in the name of the mayor and be served on the defendant at least two days prior to the date set for hearing and have attached thereto a copy of the complaint. (Code 1975, § 14-8; Code 1985, § 26-24) Sec. 16-32. - Suspension and revocation of bowling alley license. The board of commissioners may, after notice to the license holder and an opportunity to be heard, suspend or revoke any license for a bowling alley issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter or an ordinance of the city where, after such notice and an opportunity to be heard the board of commissioners finds and determines that: (1) Illegal sales of controlled substances take place on the premises with such frequency that, in the judgment of the board of commissioners, the owner or operator or manager in charge of the business knew, or in the exercise of ordinary care should have known, that such sales were taking place and such owner or operator or manager in charge has failed to take effective action to stop such sales; or (2) Persons have been permitted to loiter on the premises without legitimate business reasons who are known to the owner or operator or manager in charge of such business, or in the exercise of ordinary care should be known to them, or who are reputed to be, illegal sellers or purveyors of controlled substances. (Code 1985, § 26-25; Ord. No. 87-205, § 4, 11-24-1987) Sec. 16-33. - Occupation tax certificate and fee. (a) Each person, firm, company or corporation engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation in the city shall register with the finance director or the finance director's designee, obtain an occupation tax certificate and pay a fee each year, unless exempted. The amount of the license fee shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the offices of the city clerk and finance director. (b) All applicants for a new license or a renewal license shall be required to pay the license fee in order to defray administrative and inspection costs related to the regulation and issuance of occupation tax certificates. Fees are due at the time an application is submitted and fees are not refundable in any portion even if a license is not issued. Forms are available from the finance director or the finance director's designee. (c) All licenses are renewable on an annual basis and fees are due on or before March 15 of each calendar year. (d) Any owner or agent failing to timely renew its license is required to pay interest at the rate of 1.5 percent per month; and if said failure exists for more than 90 days, then there is hereby imposed a penalty of ten percent of the amount of said fee, all as authorized in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21. (e) In addition to the above remedies, the city finance director is authorized to and shall issue executions against the delinquent taxpayer(s) for the amount of taxes or fees due plus applicable interest. Additionally, the city municipal court is authorized to impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax or regulatory fee, said fine not to exceed $500.00 and the city municipal court is further authorized to enforce same by its contempt of powers. (Code 1985, § 26-26; Ord. No. 95-152, § 1, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001; Ord. No. 04-136, §§ 1, 2, 11-23-2004; Ord. No. 09-137, §§ 1, 2, 10-27-2009) Sec. 16-34. - Occupation tax certificate required for each business location. Each person or entity transacting, or offering to transact, business within the city, whether in connection with any other business or not, shall obtain a occupation tax certificate, pay a fee and occupation tax for each separate location in which the person or entity transacts, or offers to transact, business. (Code 1985, § 26-32; Ord. No. 95-152, § 7, 11-14-1995) Sec. 16-35. - Duration of occupation tax certificate. Each license issued under this article shall be for the calendar year, or the remaining portion thereof, and shall expire on December 31 of the year of issuance, except as may be specifically provided otherwise. (Code 1985, § 26-33; Ord. No. 95-152, § 8, 11-14-1995) Sec. 16-36. - Change of address. Any person moving their business from one location to another shall notify the finance director or the finance director's designee in writing no later than the day of moving. The same occupation tax certificate will be valid at the new location provided the new location conforms to all applicable rules and regulations, proper notification of transfer has been made, and a transfer fee has been paid. The amount of the transfer fee shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the offices of the city clerk and finance director. (Code 1985, § 26-34; Ord. No. 95-152, § 9, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001) Sec. 16-37. - Renewal of license; estimated and actual occupation tax. (a) The owner or agent of a business, trade, profession, or occupation within the city on January 1, who had been licensed in the previous year, is required to file an annual return for gross receipts on or before January 31 of each year. The return application shall be signed by the appropriate person set forth in this subsection and shall include the name, address, and dominant business activity, as well as the number of employees and amount of gross receipts of the business, trade, profession or occupation for the preceding year, and other information as may be required by the finance director or the finance director's designee, for the purpose of determining the occupation tax. (b) For each calendar year, the occupation tax will be determined from the actual results from the proceeding year, and shall constitute as the occupation tax for the respective calendar year in which the return is required to be filed. (c) The occupational tax will be based on a calculation of gross receipts times the percentages as described in section 16-65 of this chapter for each class of business for all in-state revenues. The amount of tax paid will have a floor rate of $125.00, and a ceiling rate of $9,000.00. (Code 1985, § 26-35; Ord. No. 95-152, § 10, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), (2), 8-28-2001; Ord. No. 07-125, § 2(26-35), 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 12-120, §§ 2, 3, 11-27-2012) Secs. 16-38—16-63. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAXES[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq.; municipal business license tax on depository financial institutions authorized, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93.
Sec. 16-64. - Basis for occupation tax; definitions. Each person, firm, company or corporation engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation in the city shall pay an occupation tax, based on gross receipts under each classification set forth in section 16-65(d), except those businesses, occupations or professions enumerated in section 16-66, which shall be taxed at a rate specified in this article. (1) The term "gross receipts" means the gross income of a business, trade, profession or occupation from whatever source derived before deductions or expenditures for any purpose except for sales and excise taxes and items specifically exempted by this article. (2) Any part of the gross receipts arising out of the conduct of a business, trade, profession, or occupation outside the city or the county shall be included. No occupation tax is intended to be levied upon or on account of interstate commerce; and, in any case where a person or firm is engaged in both interstate and intrastate commerce, the tax here levied is intended to be levied upon and on account of the intrastate commerce only. The tax is not levied upon gross receipts of any part of the business where such levy is prohibited by the laws of the state or of the United States. (3) Where the occupation tax is levied on persons, firms, or businesses designated as a building contractor or building trades subcontractor, and their place of business is located in the city, the tax is based only on the gross receipts of contracts and work performed within the city or the county. (4) Where business is solicited, the sale made, the merchandise or property delivered and the entire transaction completed in a city or county other than the City of Albany or Dougherty County and occupation tax certificate fees and occupational taxes are required to be paid to such other city or county for the privilege of doing such business and are so paid, then the amount of such sale shall be deducted from the total gross receipts. (5) Real estate brokers transacting business within the boundaries of Dougherty County shall pay an occupation tax based upon gross receipts. Payment of occupational tax by the real estate broker covers the associates/sales agents in the office. It is prohibited for brokers to deduct commission to associates/sales agents. (Code 1985, § 26-27; Ord. No. 95-152, § 2, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 98-115, § 1, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 07-125, § 2(26-27), 9-25-2007) Sec. 16-65. - Occupation tax. (a) For the purpose of this article, every person, firm, company or corporation engaged in a trade, business, profession, or occupation requiring licenses are classified in accordance to their main line of business as defined in the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS), and profitability classes are assigned in accordance with Statistics of Income, Business Income Tax Returns, U.S. Treasury department, Internal Revenue Service. In the case where a person, firm, company or corporation is engaged in more than one line of business, taxes will be levied on the basis of the dominant business activity of the license. (b) The separate classifications of classes 1 through 6 of the NAICS, are provided for the determination of the occupation tax to be levied as measured by gross receipts in connection with profitability ratios as measured by nationwide standards. All separate businesses, engaged in more than one business activity, shall be classified on the basis of their dominant business activity, except that person whose dominant business activity is legally exempted or otherwise limited by city or county ordinances or by state law from the tax shall be classified according to its principal subsidiary business, if any, which is subject to the levy and assessment of an occupation tax. (c) The occupation tax levied and assessed shall be determined in accordance with the following: (1) Determine whether business, trade, profession or occupation is listed in section 16-66; if so, occupation tax is amount specified; (2) All other businesses may determine their profitability class via the NAICS Profitability Class listing attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived. The tax rate for each profitability class will be on file in the offices of the city clerk and city finance department. Tax due shall be determined by multiplying the tax rate by the gross receipts. (Code 1985, § 26-28; Ord. No. 95-152, § 3, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 07-125, § 2(26-28), 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 12-120, § 4, 11-27-2012) Sec. 16-66. - Specific occupation, privilege, and industrial taxes. The following trades, businesses, professions and occupations are hereby declared not subject to the gross receipts schedule of taxation as defined in section 16-64, and are hereby taxed annually in accordance with the following schedule: (1) Professionals. Each individual practitioner of medicine, osteopathy, chiropractics, podiatry, dentistry, optometry, veterinary medicine, landscape architecture, land surveying, massage and physiotherapy, public accounting, embalming, funeral directing, civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical engineering or architecture who maintains their principal office in the city shall pay by calculating the occupation tax due based on a calculation of occupation tax as outlined in section 16-65(d), or by paying the sum of $400.00 per professional per year. No such levy shall be assessed upon or collected from any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, or any instrumentality thereof. (2) Levy of occupation tax on attorneys. As of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, an occupation tax is hereby imposed on the professional classification known as attorneys engaged in the practice of law. a. Attorneys not required to register. Notwithstanding any language to the contrary elsewhere in this article, an attorney shall not be required to register with the treasurer division. Information reported with any occupation tax payment may be retained by the treasurer division and used for those purposes allowed by applicable law. Notwithstanding any language to the contrary elsewhere in this article, an attorney shall not be required to obtain, display or maintain any city issued certificate showing that any payment or information has been submitted to the treasurer division. For the purposes of enforcement of the zoning ordinance, attorneys may be asked by the planning and development services department to submit notarized affidavits or other written information concerning the business or profession carried on at a location and the dates of operation when applying for a certificate of occupancy for new construction or renovation. Such affidavits or documents shall be used for the purposes of determining compliance with the zoning ordinance and shall not prevent the practice of the profession of law at any other location which has a valid certificate of occupancy. A refusal to submit a notarized affidavit or other written information stating whether a person engages in the practice of law at a particular location or stating the dates of operation at a location shall not be a violation of this article and shall not prevent an attorney from practicing law in the city. The chief financial officer shall document this refusal for use in any later proceeding. Where an attorney fails or refuses to provide information as to the location where they may be served with notices or citations issued in support of the enforcement of this article, the city shall direct the notices or citations to the address listed with the state bar and shall consider the failure or refusal of the attorney to provide current address information to be consent to this method of service. b. Calculation of amount of tax. An attorney who practices law in the jurisdiction of the city shall at their option have their tax rate determined, but not the time of payment, in the manner set forth in subsection (2)(a) of this section. c. Date when taxes are due; date when taxes become delinquent; amount of interest and penalties. Notwithstanding any language to the contrary elsewhere in this article, an attorney shall not be required to pay the occupation tax on the income generated from the practice of law in any calendar year until April 1 of the year following. The tax may be paid in person at the treasurer division or by mailing the tax to the treasurer division. Any tax payment made by mail shall include the name and address of the person or law firm paying the tax and the name of each attorney whose tax is being paid, so that the treasurer division may process the payment. An attorney who pays the occupation tax on their own behalf shall include the name of the law firm with which they practice, if any. Any tax paid pursuant to the option of subsection (1) of this section shall include a written submission containing sufficient information to enable the chief financial officer to determine the accuracy of the taxpayer's calculation. Taxes due from attorneys shall not be considered delinquent until June 1. An attorney who does not pay the tax prior to June 1 shall incur a penalty of ten percent of the tax due. Any taxes not paid by the due date shall accrue interest at the rate of 1½ percent per month. d. Option of the chief financial officer to send bills. Notwithstanding any language to the contrary elsewhere in this article, the chief financial officer may choose to send bills to attorneys who list their address with the State Bar of Georgia as being located in the city, including those attorneys who list only post office boxes as their addresses. An attorney who prepares and signs a notarized affidavit that they did not practice law within the jurisdiction of the city during some part of the tax year for which the tax bill was generated may have their bill adjusted for the time period stated in the affidavit when such attorney did not maintain an office within the jurisdiction of the city and/or states such other reasons why the occupation tax should be adjusted. Such adjustment shall not be made for those attorneys who elect to pay the $400.00 per practitioner fee as set forth in subsection (1) of this section unless the affidavit states that the attorney did not practice law in the jurisdiction of the city at any time during the year for which the tax bill was generated. The chief financial officer is authorized to inquire whether such affidavit matches the information maintained by the State Bar of Georgia in connection with the directives of state bar rule 1-207 and/or to take such other steps as deemed necessary to determine the accuracy of the affidavit. The submission of an affidavit requesting adjustment shall not act to prevent the imposition of penalties and interest should the chief financial officer deny the request for adjustment. The option of the chief financial officer to send bills shall not relieve attorneys from the obligation to pay any tax due for any calendar year including 2006 by April 1 of the following year. The chief financial officer may include in any bills, the unpaid tax balance from other years, including all fees and penalties and the amount of interest, which has accrued on any unpaid tax liability. The failure of the chief financial officer to list any unpaid balance on any bill shall not operate to relieve the taxpayer from liability for any balance due. It shall be a violation of this section for any attorney to willfully and intentionally misrepresent a material fact in an affidavit to avoid the payment of the occupation tax imposed by this division. The sole enforcement mechanisms for enforcement of the occupation tax levy against attorneys is limited to the following: 1. When the chief financial officer has reason to believe that an attorney has willfully and intentionally misrepresented a material fact in any affidavit submitted to treasurer division for the purposes of avoiding full payment of the occupation tax, the chief financial officer shall consult with the city attorney to determine whether such conduct should be referred to the State Bar of Georgia for investigation as to whether a violation of the Georgia Rules of Professional Conduct has occurred. 2. An attorney required to pay the occupation tax and who fails to do so in the manner provided by this article, shall be liable to have the tax and any penalties and interest collected by the issuance of execution pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. Further proceedings concerning the execution procedure employed in the enforcement of this section shall be as provided by state law. Notwithstanding any language to the contrary in other sections of this article, the use of tax executions and the reporting of any alleged misrepresentations as set forth in subsection (2)(d)1. of this section shall be the sole mechanism for enforcement of the occupation tax levy against attorneys. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the provisions of section 16-70 shall not apply to attorneys. e. Payment of city funds. Payment of city funds to attorneys or law firms employing attorneys not in compliance with the requirements of this division is not authorized; occupation tax payments to be considered in employment of attorneys by the city. 1. No individual attorney, or law firm employing such attorney, who is delinquent in the payment of the occupation tax authorized by this article, shall be paid for any legal work in which they have represented the city in any capacity, until any outstanding occupation tax liability, including all penalties and interest, has been paid in full. If the chief financial officer believes that an individual attorney, or any attorneys employed by a law firm, seeking compensation for legal services performed for the city, is/are not in full compliance with this division, the chief financial officer shall notify the individual attorney, or law firm and present a bill for the amount due. After payment of any outstanding occupation tax liability, the individual attorney, or law firm may be paid for the legal work in which they have represented the city. 2. The chief financial officer and/or the city attorney are authorized to verify that any individual attorney, or the attorneys employed by any law firm, seeking to represent the city, including without limitation, limitation, acting as bond counsel, is/are current in their occupation tax payments prior to their employment. Because of the legal and/or fiduciary relationships, which such representation of the city may create, the chief financial officer and/or the city attorney are authorized to consider compliance with the occupation tax ordinance by the individual attorneys and/or the attorneys employed by the law firm, prior to any employment by the city. f. Appeals and refund claims. Appeals of decisions of the chief financial officer and/or refund claims under this division shall be as provided under state law. (3) State and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, an occupation tax is levied upon each state and national banking association, federal savings and loan association, state banking and loan association and other depository banking institution doing business from one or more locations within the city or the county. The rate of occupation tax on any depository financial institution subject to this article shall be 0.25 percent of gross receipts of said institution during the calendar year immediately preceding the year for which the tax shall be due; provided, however, that the minimum amount of occupation tax due from any depository financial institution shall be $1,000.00 gross receipts shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Each depository financial institution subject to this tax shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city treasurer's office on or March 15 the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Said return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the state department of revenue and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said return. The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be March 15 of each tax year, provided the occupational tax for attorneys shall be due March 15 of the following year. (Code 1985, § 26-29; Ord. No. 95-152, § 4, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 03-135, § 7, 10-28-2003; Ord. No. 06-109, § 1, 3-28-2006; Ord. No. 07-125, § 2(26-29), 9-25-2007) Sec. 16-67. - Payment of estimated occupation tax. All occupation taxes fixed in accordance with this article shall be due on or before March 15 of each calendar year or within 30 days following the date the business commences operations. (Code 1985, § 26-31; Ord. No. 95-152, § 6, 11-14-1995) Sec. 16-68. - Information required on return form. (5) The report of gross receipts shall include all business done within the state; (6) All the information required by this section shall be given under oath by the owner, a member of the firm, an officer of a corporation, or by an authorized employee having knowledge of actual business done. (Code 1985, § 26-35.1; Ord. No. 95-152, § 11, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001; Ord. No. 07-125, § 2(26-35.1), 9-25-2007) Sec. 16-69. - Determination if no return made. (a) If any person, firm, company or corporation fails to make a return, the finance director or the finance director's designee shall make an estimate of the amount of the number of employees and gross receipts of the business. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the person or business failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the finance director or the finance director's designee. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001) Sec. 16-70. - Failure to file a return. (b) It shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent or clerk of the city, or any other person, to divulge or make known in any manner the amount of gross receipt, number of employees, or any particulars set forth or disclosed in any return required by this article. No. 95-152, § 15, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 01-147, § 2(1), 8-28-2001) Secs. 16-72—16-102. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS, AND VENDORS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
Sec. 16-103. - Definition. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Peddler. (1) The term "peddler" means any individual, whether a resident of this city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, for the sale of, as well as the selling, offering for sale or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he or she is collecting advance payments on such sales or not; provided, however, that such definition shall include any person, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within this city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. The term "peddler" shall include the terms "canvasser," "solicitor," or "transient or itinerant photographer." (2) The term "peddler" shall also include, "transient merchant," "itinerant merchant" or "itinerant vendor" and are defined as any person whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or boat, public room in hotels, lodginghouses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. (3) "Solicitor" includes going door-to-door (house to house) in residential areas of the city and engaging in any type of selling, seeking donations, or any other business, occupation or vocation which involves any attempt to obtain money, orders, donations, subscriptions or the like, whether such activity is done on a permanent or part-time basis or whether such activity is done for a non-profit or not-for-profit organization or enterprise. (Code 1975, § 18-1; Code 1985, § 19-16; Ord. No. 03-135, § 4, 10-28-2003; Ord. No. 11-110, §§ 1, 2, 6-28-2011) Sec. 16-104. - Exceptions to article. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: (1) Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the usual course of business; (2) Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers selling goods, wares and merchandise according to law; (3) Education or religious organizations. (Code 1975, § 18-2; Code 1985, § 19-17; Ord. No. 03-135, § 5, 10-28-2003; Ord. No. 11-110, §§ 5, 6, 6-28-2011) Sec. 16-105. - Hours of operation. (a) Uninvited solicitation prohibited. No person may go upon residential premises, not having been requested or invited, for the purpose of making contact with the occupant(s) for the purposes outlined in section 16-103 of this article where "no solicitation" or "no trespassing" sign is located at or near the residence's entrance(s). This prohibition shall also apply where a "no solicitation" or "no trespassing" sign is located at the entrance(s) to any apartment complex, condominium development or residential subdivision. Appropriate signage is available from the city manager's office, or his/her designee. (b) No call list to be established by the city manager's office. The city manager's office, or his/her designee, shall maintain a "no-call" list which shall comprise the names and addresses of occupier(s) of residential premises in the city, who do not wish to have their residence visited by peddlers, canvassers, solicitors of funds or persons selling goods or services. No peddler, canvasser, solicitor of funds or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization shall call on any resident or owner or occupier of a residential premises whose name and address appear on the "no-call" list. Every peddler or canvasser who or which obtains a certificate of registration pursuant to this article, and every peddler or canvasser, solicitor of funds or person selling goods or services is charged with the responsibility of obtaining a copy of the "no-call" list established pursuant to this section before beginning any peddling effort, canvassing effort or solicitation effort. Any person engaged in any peddling effort, canvassing effort, solicitation effort, sale of goods or services who or which calls on a residence or place of business which appears on the "no-call" list established pursuant to this section shall be subject to penalty under the provisions of sections 1-17 and 1-18 of this Code. (c) Refusal to leave. Any peddler who enters upon residential premises occupied by another must immediately leave such premises after having been requested to do so by the occupant. (d) Background check. The city manager's office, or his/her designee, shall perform a background check on the applicant for the purpose of ascertaining whether the applicant has pled guilty or no contest to or has been convicted of a felony, or a misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude. Where the background check fails to disclose any such plea or conviction, the city manager's office, or his/her designee, will issue a solicitation badge to such individual. The badge must be worn whenever the individual is engaged in solicitation/peddling and expires at the end of the calendar year of issuance. (e) Limitation of hours. No activity permitted in this article may occur prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 5:00 p.m. (f) Violations. Any violation of any provision of this [article] is punishable under sections 1-17 and 1-18 of this Code. (Code 1975, § 18-6; Code 1985, § 19-18; Ord. No. 11-110, §§ 3, 4, 6-28-2011) Sec. 16-106. - Selling ice cream, peanuts, candy, fruit, soft drinks, sandwiches or other merchandise. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale on any street, sidewalk or other public property in the city any ice cream, peanuts, candy, fruit, soft drinks, sandwiches or other merchandise, within 560 feet of any public or private school property, or to take any stand on any street or sidewalk for the purpose of selling any such merchandise within 560 feet of any public or private school property, without first obtaining permission from the principal of such public or private school. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale on any street, sidewalk or other public property in the city any ice cream, peanuts, candy, fruit, soft drinks, sandwiches or other merchandise, within 560 feet of any city ball park while organized activity is taking place therein with a permitted concession stand in place selling similar items. (Code 1975, § 18-8; Code 1985, § 19-19) Sec. 16-107. - Selling, soliciting, or delivering goods, etc., to persons in vehicles on city streets. It shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in sections 1-17 and 1-18 for any person to sell, offer to sell, solicit, give, lend, or deliver any goods, merchandise, literature, products, or other matter to persons who are in vehicles upon the traveled portion of the public streets of the city. This section shall not apply to police officers issuing summons or warnings in the performance of their official duties. (Code 1985, § 19-20; Ord. No. 86-242, § 1, 10-28-1986) Secs. 16-108—16-129. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - OUTDOOR FLEA MARKETS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 16-130. - Title. This article may also be known and cited as "The Outdoor Flea Market Ordinance of Albany, Georgia." (Code 1985, § 19-102; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. I), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-131. - Purpose. This article is adopted in order to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city by regulating outdoor flea markets. (Code 1985, § 19-103; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. I), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-132. - Function. This article establishes minimum standards for outdoor flea markets. (Code 1985, § 19-104; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. I), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-133. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accessory structure means a subordinate building or structure on the same lot, or part of the main building, occupied by or devoted to an accessory use. Booth means a structure constructed for the purpose of displaying and selling merchandise. Building means a structure having a roof, supported by columns or by walls and intended for the shelter, housing, or enclosure of any person, animal or chattel. Building inspector means the building inspector of the city, or the building inspector's authorized representative. Common area means any area or space designed for the joint use of tenants occupying flea markets. Enclosed structure means a building enclosed on all sides with permanent walls and having a permanent roof. Enforcing agencies means the inspections and code enforcement department, the license inspector, and the fire department of the city; and the county health department; charged by law with the duty to enforce the provisions of this article. Flea market stand means that part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of flea market booths, appurtenant structures or additions. Flea markets means outdoor flea markets as defined herein. Gross sales area means the sum of all areas of the flea market not devoted to parking, roadways, yard setback requirements, or open space. For the purpose of determining gross sales area, open space is defined as a continuous unit of land of at least one acre in area that is not used for any function of the flea market. Gross sales area includes all parts of all buildings in the flea market. Market management means the person who owns, or has charge, care or control of the flea market. Outdoor flea market means a principal commercial activity that occurs at a fixed location, where a proprietor, partnership, or corporation leases to vendors a booth or commercial stall from which the vendor markets his or her goods. Part or all of the flea market is conducted outside of an enclosed structure; sidewalk sales are not included under this definition. Each vending location shall have access via an internal walkway, courtyard, path, or common area. Prepared food sales means the sale of any food item subjected to a special process or treatment (ex: heating, frying, mixing, slicing, etc.) before being sold to the consumer, and generally intended for consumption on the flea market premises. Public street means a public way which affords principal means of access to abutting properties. Retail food sales means the sale of nonprepared, fresh food items (i.e., produce, farm products, seafood, and meat) not generally intended for consumption on the flea market premises. Right-of-way means an area, either public or private, over which the legal right of passage exists. Service buildings means a structure housing sanitary, operational, office, recreational, maintenance and other facilities built to conform to required standards. Structure includes "arranged," "designed," "constructed," "altered," "converted," "rented," "leased," or "intended to be used." (Code 1985, § 19-105; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. II, §§ 2.00, 2.01), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-134. - Inspections. The inspections and code enforcement department can make inspections as necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this article as authorized by the city building code. (Code 1985, § 19-107; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.02), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-135. - Revocation of permits. As authorized by the city building code, building permits for any flea market may be revoked by the inspections and code enforcement department when a flea market is found to be in violation of this article. (Code 1985, § 19-108; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.03), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-136. - Revocation of licenses. (a) Any permit or license issued pursuant to this article for the operation of a flea market may be revoked by the board of city commissioners, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: (1) Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit or license; (2) Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by the permittee in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; (3) Any violation by the permittee of this article; (4) The conviction of the permittee of any felony, or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; (5) The conducting of the business permitted under this article by the permittee in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. (b) Notice of hearing for revocation of a permit issued under this article shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be served on the permittee by handing the same personally to the person in charge of the permitted business, or by mailing the same, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the permittee's last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. (c) The giving of such notice shall suspend the permit pending the outcome of the hearing, and business operations under the permit shall cease. (Code 1985, § 19-109; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.04), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-137. - Emergencies. (a) Whenever the director of the inspections and code enforcement department finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, including violations of any of the applicable rules and regulations of the county health department or the state department of public health, the director of the inspections and code enforcement department may without notice or hearing issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency, and requiring that such action be taken as he or she may deem necessary to meet the emergency, including the suspension of the permit or license. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon petition to the board of zoning appeals, such person shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. (b) The provisions of section 16-138 shall be applicable to the hearing and the order issued thereafter. (Code 1985, § 19-110; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.05), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-138. - Appeals. (a) An appeal may be taken to the board of zoning appeals of any person, firm, or corporation, or by any officer, department, board or bureau affected by a decision of the building inspector. Such appeals shall be taken within such time as shall be prescribed by the board of zoning appeals by general rule by filing with the planning commission a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. (b) The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the notice and the suspension, except in the case of an order issued under section 16-137. (Code 1985, § 19-111; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.06), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-139. - Enforcement. Any person violating or neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished according to the general penalties described in sections 1-17 and 1-18. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1985, § 19-113; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. VI, § 6.08), 5-26-1992) Secs. 16-140—16-166. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 16-167. - Permits and licenses required. (a) Building permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to locate a flea market or to construct, alter or extend any flea market within the limits of the city unless such person holds a valid building permit issued by the inspections and code enforcement department. The right to construct, alter or extend any flea market shall expire 180 days after the issuance of a permit. (b) Certificate of occupancy. It shall be unlawful and prohibited to use or permit the use of any flea market land, building or structure for which a building permit is required, and to use or permit to be used any flea market building or structure hereafter altered, extended, erected, repaired, or moved, until the building inspector shall have issued a certificate of occupancy stating that the provisions of these regulations have been complied with. (c) Business license. The flea market management must be licensed by the city for the operation of an outdoor flea market. This license shall be a license of privilege that may be revoked by the city commission according to section 16-136. (1) All vendors shall be licensed for business specifically at the flea market location by the city; (2) All vendors not licensed for business specifically at the flea market location by the city shall file a certificate of registration with the flea market management, and shall pay the registration fee, required for daily flea market retail sales without a business license for each day that merchandise is displayed for sale. This fee is assessed by the city and collected for the city by the market management; (3) Vendors selling used merchandise obtained in the county shall comply with section 48-111, when applicable, regulating secondhand dealers, requiring disclosure to city police of all secondhand good sources, and other requirements; (4) Any vendor operating any business in the city outside of the flea market, and selling the same or similar merchandise at the flea market location, shall obtain a business license from the city for the flea market location, and shall pay a license fee based on the items available for sale by the merchant; (5) A city business license or valid certificate of registration shall be continuously displayed in a conspicuous location on the front of each flea market booth. A certificate of registration is valid only if it is labeled by the market management to indicate payment of the registration fee, required for daily flea market retail sales without a business license. (Code 1985, § 19-121; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. III, § 3.01), 5-26-1992) Secs. 16-168—16-187. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
Sec. 16-188. - Flea market locations; zoning district requirements. (a) Flea market location. No flea market structure or facility shall be located within 300 feet of any residential zoning district boundary. (b) Zoning district requirements. Flea markets shall comply with all zoning ordinance area, height, setback, lot coverage, and signage requirements of the zoning district within which the market is located. If the standards of the zoning ordinance conflict with standards of this article, the more restrictive shall apply. (Code 1985, § 19-131; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. IV, § 4.00), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-189. - Site improvement requirements. (a) Condition of site not to create hazard, etc. The condition of soil, groundwater level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, noise, odors, or other adverse influences. (b) Soil and ground cover. Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every flea market shall be paved, or covered with stone screenings, or other solid material, or protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust and/or mud. (c) Site drainage requirements. The ground surface in all parts of every flea market shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner in order to eliminate water pockets, low areas or bogs. (Code 1985, § 19-132; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. IV, § 4.01), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-190. - Setbacks, buffer strips and screening. (a) All flea market structures and parking facilities shall be located at least 20 feet from any public street right-of-way or highway right-of-way, and at least 20 feet from the property boundary lines. (b) All flea markets shall be provided with screening of a well-maintained opaque fence separating the market and adjacent zoning and uses, except along public road frontage used for primary access to the flea market. Said screening shall be a minimum of six feet in height. (c) Flea market sites shall be screened from view along street right-of-way frontage used for primary access to the flea market in C-3 and CR districts in accordance with section 4.30g(2) (Protective screening and fencing), of the zoning ordinance. (Code 1985, § 19-133; Ord. No. 92-128, (art. IV, § 4.02), 5-26-1992) Sec. 16-191. - Street system and walks. (a) Streets and roads. All flea markets shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets, or roads, or highways. Access shall not be permitted from residential streets. Access to flea markets shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards at the entrance or exit and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. The entrance road connecting the market with a public street or road shall comply with the requirements of section 6.02a.(7) of the city zoning ordinance. (b) Walks. All pedestrian access to every flea market shall be paved, and shall be of adequate width for the intended use. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. (Code 1985, § 19-134; Ord.
