Such ordinance or work order shall constitute the permit. (b) Sewers constructed by others. The following shall be the permit requirements for sewers constructed by others: (1) Contractors performing work for the City of Albany, Georgia. The notice to proceed shall constitute the permit authorizing construction. (2) All others. No work shall be performed on any sewer or in any existing or future city street, alley or right-of-way unless and until plans have been submitted to and approved in writing by the director of engineering or the director of engineering's designee. Upon approval of the plans, the director of engineering shall then issue a written permit authorizing construction of the sewers and transmit a set of the approved plans to the director of public works or sewer superintendent. (3) Conformity. Sewer construction shall conform to all pertinent OSHA standards. (4) Marked. All sewer construction shall be marked with magnetic location tape per the Utility Protection Center Regulations (O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq.). (c) Taps. The following shall be the permit requirements for taps: (1) Cleanout construction and location of existing taps. a. Cleanouts constructed in accordance with city standards will be installed at the end of each tap whether laid by the city or duly authorized contractor. b. Location of existing taps. 1. The city will locate unused existing sewer taps at no charge for location service. 2. When buildings are razed, the person responsible for the demolition shall locate the existing building sewer at the property line and call the city public works department to reference the tap. No charge is made for this service. When the building sewer is not located at the property line and the city public works department has to make additional trips to reference the tap, the additional cost will be billed to the person responsible for demolition. c. Reuse of existing taps. Taps will be reused by the next occupant provided the tap is in good condition and sufficient in size, as determined by the superintendent of the sewer systems division. The tap reuse fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time, and made available for public examination in the offices of the public works department and the city clerk, will be assessed. d. Locations subject to backup conditions. At locations where backups are known or are expected to occur, the director of engineering will recommend in writing the installation of a manhole containing a plug valve and a check valve for backflow prevention. Where backups are known to occur, the city will provide all equipment and labor to make the installation if the property owner will furnish all materials. At undeveloped locations where the director of engineering has reason to believe back-up conditions may occur, the director of engineering will recommend in writing that the owner make the installation of the manhole and valves at the owner's expense. Subsequent flooding damages will not be the responsibility of the city if the owner does not make the installation. If the owner later experiences backup conditions, the owner will pay the total cost, if he or she desires to have the backflow prevention installed. (2) Construction by city forces. a. All taps connecting to any sewer maintained, owned or controlled by the city will be installed by city forces or an authorized contractor. The work order shall constitute the permit. b. On new work, wyes will be installed during construction. c. On existing sewers, where possible, a boring or drilling machine shall be used to make the connection to the existing pipe. (3) Construction by duly authorized contractors. a. Taps utilizing wyes will be installed by contractors where the sewer is in a street, alley or easement which is to be paved as part of a subdivision development or under contract to the city. b. Taps utilizing wyes will be installed in all other areas during construction by contractors to serve the abutting property where sewers being installed are deeper than ten feet. c. A record drawing showing the location of all taps will be required. (4) Fees for taps. a. Tap fees vary in cost according to location and conditions. Taps are classified under the following headings: Dirt alley. Paved alley. Dirt street. Paved street. Existing tap reuse. The appropriate fees shall be as established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. b. Where the cost of the sewer was either not assessed against the abutting property or was held in abeyance, the sewer tap fee shall be the actual assessment plus the appropriate tap fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. If the actual assessment is unknown, the tap fee shall be the current maximum sanitary sewer assessment rate applied to the abutting footage plus the appropriate tap fee. c. Where the sewer is located outside the city limits, the sewer tap fee shall be equal to the actual assessment (if it could have been made) plus the appropriate tap fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. If the value of the actual assessment is unknown, then the tap fee shall be the current maximum sanitary sewer assessment rate applied to the abutting footage plus the appropriate tap fee. d. For sewer extensions or new sewer systems being made by private developers, the developers will pay the entire costs of such extensions or developments. No "rebate" or charges for sewer taps will be made or collected by the city and rebated or refunded to the developers over any period of time, for, or under any circumstances. e. Whenever the city has constructed in the past or does construct in the future any sanitary sewer line, the cost of which has not been assessed against the adjoining property owners, the director of public works shall determine and fix a sewer connection fee, in addition to the standard sewer tapping fee and sewer development fee, with respect to each property owner which shall be equal to the amount which would have been assessed against the property had the sewer line been constructed and assessed during the calendar year in which construction was completed, adjusted for inflation as measured by the consumer price index maintained by the United States government; provided, however, that the adjusted cost shall not be less than the actual original cost, nor more than twice the actual original cost. Any property owner tapping into the sanitary sewer line shall first pay the sewer connection fee, and other standard fees, so fixed and assessed. (d) Construction. After all requirements for permits and fees have been met, all building sewers shall be constructed in strict accord with the city plumbing code. Building sewers outside the city limits, but which will connect to the city sewer, shall also conform to all city regulations. (Code 1985, § 14-134; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-133. - Inspection. (a) Sewers. All sewers laid by other than city forces shall be inspected by the city engineering department as provided in the city standard specifications. (b) Taps. All taps and cleanouts installed by other than city forces shall be inspected by the city engineering department as provided in the city standard specifications. Record drawings showing the correct location of all taps in sewer extensions or subdivision development shall be provided to the director of engineering before the sewer system will be approved and accepted by the city. (c) Construction. All building sewers shall be inspected and approved by the city plumbing inspector before being covered with earth or other material. All materials shall conform to those currently approved under the city plumbing code. Building sewers six inches and larger in diameter shall conform in all respects to city standard specifications for sewer construction and will be inspected during construction by the city engineering department. (d) Single services. A building sewer shall serve only one premises or building. Where there are two or more buildings presently connected to a single building sewer and the ownership of the buildings becomes divided, then each building or premises must be separately connected to a city tap. (Code 1985, §§ 14-135, 27-24; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-4), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-134. - Assessment. (a) Assessment roll. The following shall be the requirements for the assessment roll: (1) Required information. After the completion of any sanitary sewer project that has been constructed under an ordinance, either by contract or city forces, and any part is to be assessed against the abutting property owners, an assessment roll shall be prepared which includes the following information: a. Ordinance number authorizing improvement; b. The name and portion of street, alley, or easement where sewer was constructed; c. The names and addresses of the owners of the property abutting on the improvement and the number of linear or front feet owned by each; d. The date work commenced and the date of completion of the project; e. An itemized statement or the material, labor, insurance, equipment rental and percent of supervision and contingencies; f. The number of linear feet of sewer constructed; g. The total cost of the improvement; h. The city's part, if any, of the cost; i. The abutting owner's proportionate part of the cost; j. The abutting owner's cost per foot of the improvement; and k. If the abutting owner's cost per foot of improvements is greater than the maximum cost per foot, then the maximum cost per foot in effect at the passage of the ordinance will be shown and used for assessment purposes. (2) Filing. The assessment roll shall be filed with the city finance department. (b) Duties of city finance department. As soon as the assessment roll shall be filed with the city finance department, a statement shall be sent to each abutting property owner showing the amount due and will include the following: (1) The number of front feet chargeable to the abutting owner; (2) The number of linear or front feet improved; (3) The total cost thereof; (4) The amount chargeable to the city; (5) The amount chargeable to the abutting owners; (6) The cost per front foot to the abutting owners; (7) The amount due from the person notified; and (8) Assessment payment date. If the face amount of assessment is not paid within 30 days from billing date, percent of interest on unpaid amount will be shown. (c) Methods of computations. The following shall be the methods of computation: (1) Abutting footage. a. Regular lots. The abutting dimension of either rectangular or parallelogram shaped lots shall be used as the assessable footage. b. Irregularly shaped lots. The average dimension of the abutting side and the side opposite shall be used as the assessable footage. c. Extremely odd-shaped lots. The assessable footage shall be equal to the total area of the lot divided by the average depth or width of the more regular shaped lots in the immediate vicinity. (2) Size of sewer to be assessed. When the sewer laid is larger than eight inches in diameter, the amount to be assessed shall be the total cost less 120 percent of the difference in the cost of the pipe actually laid and that of eight-inch pipe, multiplied by the number of feet of sewer. (Code 1985, §§ 27-25, 14-136; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-5), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-135. - Maintenance and use of sewers. (a) Building sewers. The following shall be the maintenance requirements for building sewers: (1) Responsibility. Building sewers are the responsibility of the property owner. The city does not maintain them. (2) Exceptions. When authorized by the city manager, the sewer systems division of public works will clear stop ups of building sewers. The person requesting aid will be billed for 200 percent of the actual cost involved including labor and equipment rental. (b) Taps. The following shall be the maintenance requirements for taps: (1) Responsibility. Maintenance of taps is the responsibility of the city. No charge shall be made by the city for cleaning stop up of taps. (2) Stopped taps. Taps stopped up by the introduction of prohibited materials into the building sewer will be cleared by the sewer systems division. The person causing the stop up shall be billed 200 percent of the actual cost involved in clearing the stoppage. Repeat violations may be fined as provided in sections 60-162 through 60-165. (3) Penality. Persons claiming stop ups in the tap shall be billed 200 percent of the actual costs involved if investigation reveals the stop up is in the building sewer rather than in the tap. (c) Sewers. There are no private sewers in city streets, alleys, or rights-of-way and none will be permitted. Sewer maintenance is the responsibility of the city. (1) Sewer stopped up by prohibited materials. These sewers shall be cleared by the city, and the person causing the obstruction shall be billed 200 percent of the actual cost involved in the cleaning of the stoppage. Repeat violations may be fined as provided in sections 60-162 through 60-165. a. In the event a property owner has a stopped up sewer and there is no cleanout at the property line, an agreement can be signed by the property owner that authorizes city personnel to install a cleanout at the property line. b. If the stop-up or problem was in the building or house sewer line, the property owner will be billed for the cost of installation of the cleanout, which is equal to the amount as established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time and made available for public examination in the offices of the city clerk and public works department. c. If the stop-up or problem was in the city tap, the property owner will not be billed for the cleanout installation. (2) New sewer laid by contractors. It is the responsibility of the contractor to clean the sewer line prior to the final video inspection. In the event the contractor fails to do the cleaning, the contractor shall be billed 200 percent of the actual cost involved in cleaning the sewer. (3) Responsibility. Backup prevention devices are the responsibility of the property owner. The city does not maintain them and will not do so unless authorized by the city manager. The owner requesting such maintenance shall be billed 200 percent of the actual cost involved. (4) Claim for damages. Claims for damages caused by malfunctioning of a city sewer shall be submitted in writing to the city risk manager. The sewer systems division shall be notified by either the city risk manager or the owner during the actual occurrence so that a written report can be made for the city. (Code 1985, §§ 14-137, 27-25, 27-26; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-5), (28-6), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-136. - Sewer extension policy. (a) Existing development within 200 feet of city sewer, where capacity is available, is required to connect to city sewer if an existing septic tank or private sewer fails. The appropriate fees would be paid to the city for providing this service including tap fees, sewer development charge, and the cost of extending the sewer main to the property if required. The developer may be required by the director of engineering to hire a contractor to install the sewer main and tap. The work shall be inspected by the city and the developer would then pay the city a sewer development charge. (b) New development within 200 feet of city sewer, where capacity is available, is required to connect to city sewer. The appropriate fees would be paid to the city for providing this service including tap fees, sewer development charges, and the cost of extending the sewer main to the property if required. The developer may be required by the director of engineering to hire a contractor to install the sewer main and tap. The work would be inspected by the city and the developer would then pay the city a sewer development charge. (c) Areas not served by city sewer can obtain city sewer service in one of the following ways: (1) Provided capacity is available and sewer service is within 1,000 feet of unserved property, property owners within the city limits may petition the city for sewer service. All property owners to be affected by the sewer extension would be notified of the petition by certified mail and would have 30 days to vote for or against the project. If 51 percent or more of the property owners to be affected are in favor of the project, the city commission by a majority vote could pass an ordinance to do the work and assess all property owners to be served by the extension. (2) Provided capacity is available and sewer service is within 1,000 feet of unserved property located within the city limits, the city commission can pass an ordinance after a public hearing, for public health, safety, and welfare reasons, with a majority vote to extend sewer service to this area and assess all property owners to be served by the extension. (3) Provided capacity is available and sewer service is located more than 1,000 feet from unserved property located within the city limits, but based on the existing development patterns and/or the existing land use map, the development density in the service area of the sewer extension is or could be 3.25 units per acre, the city commission may pass an ordinance, after a public hearing, for public health, safety, and welfare reasons, to extend sewer service to this area and assess all property owners to be served by the extension. (4) A developer of property, inside the city limits, can submit plans to the director of engineering for approval to extend sewer service to a new development such as a subdivision. Sewer shall be extended to the limits of the property to allow future developments access to sewer. Upon approval of plans, the developer can hire a contractor, provided capacity is available to extend the sewer. Developer would pay for all costs with installing sewer within a new subdivision. Taps would be installed to the lots by the contractor. All development charges would be paid as building permits are issued. The city will pay for increased capacity, extra depth or increased pipe size if the director of engineering determines it necessary. (5) Provided capacity is available, the county can request the city to provide sewer service to an unserved area located in the unincorporated part of the county. The county would pay the city for all costs of construction and all other associated costs. A sewer development charge would also be due as building permits are issued. Secs. 60-137—60-155. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 60-156. - Notification of violation. A notice of violation (NOV) will be issued by the pretreatment coordinator whenever an IU has violated the article, wastewater discharge permit, or other written orders. The IU must respond in writing to the pretreatment coordinator and present an explanation of the cause of the violation, within five business days from such occurrence. In addition, the IU must present, within 30 days of the day when the violation occurred, a plan for correction and prevention of such violations in the future. Submission of this plan in no way relieves the IU for any liability for any violations occurring before and after receipt of the NOV. (Code 1985, § 14-108; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-157. - Consent orders. A consent order is a written agreement between the city and the IU for implementing a voluntary remedial action of violations by the IU. This written agreement will include specific actions to be taken by the IU to correct the noncompliance within a time period specified in the document. (Code 1985, § 14-109; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-158. - Show cause hearing. The pretreatment coordinator may order an IU which causes or contributes to a violation of the article, wastewater discharge permit, or other written orders, to show cause why a proposed enforcement action should not be taken. The notice will be delivered to the principal executive, general partner, or corporate officer of higher ranking that is in charge of operations at the local IU facility. The notice will include the day and time of the hearing and will be served personally or by certified mail (return receipt requested) at least ten days prior to the hearing. (Code 1985, § 14-110; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-159. - Administrative compliance order. When the IU has violated or continues to violate the article or permit or other administrative enforcement actions, the director of public works can issue an administrative compliance order (ACO) to the responsible party. The ACO specifies a time period when sewer service will be discontinued unless the appropriate corrective actions are taken by the IU. The ACO may require that the IU prepare a corrective action plan (CAP). This CAP will outline the specific actions and compliance schedule of the remedial project. The specific CAP content form will be available for public examination or distribution in the offices of the public works department. (Code 1985, § 14-111; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-160. - Emergency suspensions. (a) The director of public works may suspend the wastewater treatment service and/or wastewater permit of an industrial user whenever such suspension is necessary in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge presenting or causing an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons, the POTW, or the environment. (b) Any user notified of a suspension of the wastewater treatment service and/or the wastewater permit shall immediately stop or eliminate its contribution. In the event of a user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the director of public works shall take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream, or endangerment to any individuals. The director of public works shall allow the user to recommence its discharge when the endangerment has passed, unless the termination proceedings set forth in section 60-161 are initiated against the user. An industrial user who is the subject of a suspension order under this subsection shall have the right to appeal to the director of public works from such suspension, but such suspension shall remain in full force and effect pending such hearing and the decision of the director of public works pursuant thereto. (c) An industrial user which is responsible, in whole or in part, for imminent endangerment shall submit a detailed written statement to the director of public works describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence prior to the date of the hearing described in section 60-158. (Code 1985, §§ 14-114, 27-30; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10), 4-23-1991) Sec. 60-161. - Termination of permit. (a) Significant industrial users proposing to discharge into the POTW, must first obtain a wastewater discharge permit from the department of public works. Any user who violates the following conditions of this article or a wastewater discharge permit or order, or any applicable or state and federal law, is subject to permit termination: (1) Violation of permit conditions; (2) Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; (3) Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater constituents and characteristics; or (4) Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring, or sampling. (b) Noncompliant industrial users will be notified of the proposed termination of their wastewater permit and be offered an opportunity to show cause under section 60-158 why the proposed action should not be taken. (Code 1985, §§ 14-115, 27-30; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-162. - Judicial enforcement remedies. If any person discharges sewage, industrial wastes, or other wastes into the wastewater disposal system contrary to the provisions of this article or any order or permit issued hereunder, the director of public works, through the city attorney, may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in the municipal court. (Code 1985, §§ 14-116, 27-30, 27-31; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10), (28-11), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-163. - Injunctive relief. Whenever an industrial user has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article or permit or order issued hereunder, the director of public works, through counsel may petition the court for its issuance of a preliminary or permanent injunction or both (as may be appropriate) which restrains or compels the activities on the part of the industrial user. The director of public works shall have such remedies to collect these fees as it has to collect other sewer service charges. The director of public works may also initiate nuisance abatement proceedings in the municipal court of the city, as an alternate remedy. (Code 1985, §§ 14-117, 27-30—27-32; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10)—(28-12), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-164. - Civil penalties. (a) Any industrial user who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article or any order or permit issued hereunder, shall be liable for a civil penalty of up to at least $1,000.00 plus actual damages incurred by the POTW per violation per day for as long as the violation continues. In addition to the above described penalty and damages, the director of public works may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with the enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses. (b) The director of public works shall petition the municipal court of the city or any state court having jurisdiction to impose, assess, and recover such sums. In determining amount of liability, the municipal court of the city or any state court having jurisdiction shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration, any economic benefit gained through the industrial user's violation, corrective actions by the industrial user, the compliance history of the user, and any other factor as justice requires. ((Code 1985, §§ 14-118, 27-30—27-32; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10)—(28-12), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-165. - Criminal prosecution. (a) Any industrial user who willfully or negligently violates any provision of this article or any orders or permits issued hereunder shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation per day or imprisonment for not more than six months or both. (b) Any industrial user who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certifications in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or wastewater permit, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 per violation per day or imprisonment for not more than six months or both. (Code 1985, §§ 14-119, 27-30, 27-31; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-10), (28-11), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-166. - Performance bonds. The director of public works may decline to reissue a permit to any industrial user which has failed to comply with the provisions of this article or any order or previous permit issued hereunder unless such user first files with it a satisfactory bond, payable to the POTW, in a sum not to exceed a value determined by the director of public works to be necessary to achieve consistent compliance. (Code 1985, § 14-120; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-167. - Liability insurance. The director of public works may decline to reissue a permit to any industrial user which has failed to comply with the provisions of this article or any order or previous permit issued hereunder, unless the industrial user first submits proof that it has obtained financial assurances sufficient to restore or repair POTW damage caused by its discharge. (Code 1985, § 14-121; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-168. - Water supply severance. Whenever an industrial user has been found after hearing to be in violation of the provisions of this article or an order issued hereunder, water service to the industrial user may be severed and service will only recommence, at the user's expense, after it has satisfactorily demonstrated its ability to comply. (Code 1985, § 14-122; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-169. - Public nuisances. Any violation of the prohibitions or effluent limitations of this article or permit or order issued hereunder is hereby declared a public nuisance and shall be corrected or abated as directed by the director of public works or the director of public works' designee. Any person creating a public nuisance shall be subject to the provisions of the citation established by the city Code governing such nuisances, including reimbursing the POTW for any costs incurred in removing, abating, or remedying said nuisance. (Code 1985, § 14-123; Ord. No. 05-111, 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-170. - Informant rewards. The director of public works has the option to pay up to $500.00 for information leading to the discovery of noncompliance by an industrial user. In the event that the information provided results in an administrative fine or civil penalty levied against the user, the director of public works is authorized to disperse up to ten percent of the collected fine or penalty to the informant. However, a single reward payment may not exceed $10,000.00. (Code 1985, § 14-124; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Secs. 60-171—60-193. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - USE REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 60-194. - Prohibited discharge standards. (a) General prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. (b) Specific prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances, or wastewater: (1) Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees Celsius) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21; (2) Wastewater having a pH less than 5.0 or more than 12.5, or otherwise causing corrosive structural damage to the POTW or equipment; (3) Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause obstruction of the flow in the POTW resulting in interference (but in no case solids greater than 2.5 inches in any dimension); (4) Pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, will cause interference with the POTW; (5) Wastewater having a temperature greater than 113 degrees Fahrenheit (45 degrees Celsius), or which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment plant resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater which causes the temperature at the introduction into the treatment plant to exceed 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius); (6) Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin, in amounts that will cause interference or pass through; (7) Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems; (8) Trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the director of public works in accordance with section 60-223; (9) Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids, or other wastewater which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance or repair; (10) Wastewater which imparts color which cannot be removed by the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the treatment plant's effluent, thereby violating the city's NPDES permit; (11) Wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes except in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; (12) Stormwater, surface water, groundwater, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, condensate, deionized water, noncontact cooling water, and unpolluted wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the director of public works; (13) Sludges, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes; (14) Medical wastes, except as specifically authorized by the director of public works in a wastewater discharge permit; (15) Wastewater causing, alone or in conjunction with other sources, the treatment plant's effluent to fail a toxicity test; (16) Detergents, surface-active agents, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW; (17) Fats, oils, or greases of animal or vegetable origin in concentrations greater than 100 mg/l, or other substances that will solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 35 degrees Fahrenheit (1.7 degrees Celsius) and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65.6 degrees Celsius); or (18) Wastewater causing repeat readings on an explosion hazard meter at the point of discharge into the POTW. Pollutants, substances, or wastewater prohibited by this section shall not be processed or stored in such a manner that they could be discharged to the POTW. (Code 1985, §§ 14-65, 27-28; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-8), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-195. - National categorical pretreatment standards. The categorical pretreatment standards found at 40 CFR ch. 1, subch. N, §§ 403—471 are hereby incorporated. (1) Where a categorical pretreatment standard is expressed only in terms of either the mass or the concentration of a pollutant in wastewater, the director of public works may impose equivalent concentration or mass limits in accordance with 40 CFR 403.6(c). (2) When wastewater subject to a categorical pretreatment standard is mixed with wastewater not regulated by the same standard, the director of public works shall impose an alternate limit using the combined wastestream formula in 40 CFR 403.6(e). (3) A user may obtain a variance from a categorical pretreatment standard if the user can prove, pursuant to the procedural and substantive provisions in 40 CFR 403.13, that factors relating to its discharge are fundamentally different from the factors considered by EPA when developing the categorical pretreatment standard. a. Industrial user must develop a pilot testing program at the POTW. This program will include a pilot unit or a prototype treatment plant, of reasonable scale, to conduct treatment of actual influent wastewater, spiked with proportional synthetic mass quantities of expected concentration of the concerned contaminant. b. User will present to the city a pilot testing program (PTP) plan with the following requirements: 1. A detailed description of the objectives of the PTP plan. Users shall provide wastewater treatment as necessary to comply with this article and shall achieve compliance with all categorical pretreatment standards, local limits, and the prohibitions set out in section 60-194 within the time limitations specified by EPA, the state, or the director of public works, whichever is more stringent. Any facilities necessary for compliance shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans describing such facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the director of public works for review, and shall be acceptable to the director of public works before such facilities are constructed. (b) The director of public works may require any person discharging into the POTW to install and maintain, on their property and at their expense, a suitable storage and flow-control facility to ensure equalization of flow. An accidental discharge/slug control plan shall address, at a minimum, the following: (1) Description of discharge practices, including nonroutine batch discharges; (2) Description of stored chemicals; (3) Procedures for immediately notifying the director of public works of any accidental or slug discharge, as required by section 60-194; and (4) Procedures to prevent adverse impact from any accidental or slug discharge. Such procedures include, but are not limited to, inspection and maintenance of storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant size runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants including solvents and/or measures and equipment for emergency response. (2) The director of public works, the pretreatment coordinator, or city technicians shall have the right to set up on the user's property, or require installation of such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the user's operations. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the user at its own expense. (4) Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the user at the written or verbal request of the pretreatment coordinator and shall not be replaced. No. 91-132, § 1(28-8), (28-10), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-362. - Search warrants. The director of public works shall publish annually, in the largest daily newspaper published in the municipality where the POTW is located, a list of the users which, during the previous 12 months, were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. The term "significant noncompliance" shall mean: (1) Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined as those in which 66 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken during a six-month period exceed the daily maximum limit or average limit for the same pollutant parameter by any amount; (2) Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined as those in which 33 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equals or exceeds the product of the daily maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oils and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); (3) Any other discharge violation that the director of public works believes has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through, including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public; (4) Any discharge of pollutants that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment, or has resulted in the director of public works' exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; (5) Failure to meet, within 90 days of the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; (6) Failure to provide within 30 days after the due date, any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadlines, special self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; (7) Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or (8) Any other violations which the director of public works determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. Sec. 60-387. - Treatment upsets. (a) Any industrial user which experiences an upset in operation that places it in a temporary state of noncompliance, which is not the result of operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation, shall inform the director of public works thereof immediately upon becoming aware of the upset. Where such information is given orally, a written report thereof shall be filed by the user within five days. The report shall contain: (1) A description of the upset, its cause and impact on the discharger's compliance status; (2) The duration of noncompliance, including exact dates and times of noncompliance, and if the noncompliance is continuing, the time by which compliance is reasonably expected to be restored; (3) All steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of such an upset. (b) An industrial user which complies with the notification provisions of this section in a timely manner shall have an affirmative defense to any enforcement action brought by the director of public works for any noncompliance with this article, or an order or permit issued hereunder by the user, which arises out of violations attributable to and alleged to have occurred during the period of the documented and verified upset. (c) The affirmative defense shall be in accordance with the specifications presented in 40 CFR 403.16. An industrial user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or other relevant evidence that: (1) An upset occurred and the industrial user can identify the cause of the upset: (2) The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and workman-like manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance procedures; (3) The industrial user has submitted the information described in subsection (a) of this section to the director of public works within the time limits specified therein. (d) In any enforcement proceeding the industrial user seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof. (e) In the usual exercise of prosecutorial discretion, city enforcement personnel should review any claims that noncompliance was caused by an upset. No determinations made in the course of the review constitute final city action subject to judicial review. Industrial users will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards. (f) The industrial user shall control production or all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost or fails. (Code 1985, §§ 14-125, 27-28; Ord. No. 91-132, § 1(28-8), 4-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Secs. 60-388—60-417. - Reserved. DIVISION 10. - CHARGES AND FEES
Sec. 60-418. - Sewer usage and treatment charges. (a) Established. It is hereby determined necessary for the protection of public health, safety, welfare and convenience of the city to fix and collect charges upon all premises or facilities served by sewerage connection with the city's sewer. (b) Use of proceeds. The revenue received from the collection of such charges as hereinafter authorized, together with all other revenue derived from the operation of the sewer system shall be deposited with the municipal revenue collector and credited to the sanitary sewer enterprise fund and shall be used for the operation and maintenance of the POTW and incidental expenses connected therewith, to pay debt requirements on revenue bonds issued, to provide funds for the construction, improvement, repair and extension of the sewage system and POTW infrastructure, to acquire necessary easements or to purchase land and to provide funds for the necessary debt reserves and improvements but shall not be used for the construction of storm sewers. (c) Determination of amounts. There is hereby charged and assessed to each premises or facility served by the connection with the sewer system, or otherwise discharging sewage, industrial wastes, water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into the sewer system, a sewer service charge and assessment payable as hereafter provided, and in the amount determinable as follows: (1) The said sewer service charge shall be based upon the quantity of water used by the said premises or facility therein or thereon as the same is measured by a water meter or meters there in use, or as otherwise currently established. (2) The monthly sewer service charge for industrial/commercial usage shall consist of the base monthly charge plus a charge per total pounds of BOD plus a charge per total pounds of TSS as determined by sampling and a charge per 1,000 gallons of water, including adjustments thereto, consumed within the county whether within or without the corporate limits of the city. The amount of these charges shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. (3) The monthly sewer service charge for the industrial/commercial usage with no sampling history shall consist of the base monthly charge plus a combined charge per 1,000 gallons consumed based on consumption of BOD and TSS. The amount of these charges shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. (4) The monthly sewer service charge for residential usage shall consist of the base monthly charge plus a combined charge per 1,000 gallons consumed based on consumption of BOD and TSS. The average consumption billed during the months of January, February, and March will be used for computing the sewer service charge for the next 12 months. For new residential billings with no consumption history, billing will be based on a consumption of 6,000 gallons per month. The amount of these charges shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the public works department. (5) Water used from private sources shall be metered as required in the independent water supply subsection (d) of this section and the city sewer service charge shall be the applicable charge for industrial/commercial or residential usage. (d) Independent water supply; installation of meter. In the event a lot, parcel of land, premises or facility discharging sewage, industrial waste, water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into the city's sewer system, or which ultimately enters the sewer system, is supplied either whole or in part, with water from wells, or any source other than the Albany Water, Gas, and Light Commission, then such wells or other source of supply shall be registered with the Albany Water, Gas and Light Commission and, if the water from said wells or other supply is not measured by a water meter, the owner or occupant shall, at his or her own cost, install and maintain a meter or meters on said supplies in such a location and in such a manner as is satisfactory to the Albany Water, Gas and Light Commission. These meters shall serve as a control for the establishment of the sewer service charge and shall be read monthly or bimonthly by members of the Albany Water, Gas and Light Commission. In selected cases, certain industries may read and report these readings to Albany Water, Gas and Light Commission. (e) Additional meters. Where it can be shown to the satisfaction of the director of public works that a significant portion of the water as measured by the water meter or meters does not enter the sewer system, then the director of public works may require or permit the installation of additional meters or other devices as may be deemed necessary to establish that portion that does enter the sewer system, and the corrected meter flow will be used for billing of the sewer service charge. All such additional facilities will be provided by the owner of the premises concerned or other interested parties at no expense to the city. (f) More than one residential unit served by a single meter. When more than one residential unit is served by single meter, the sewer service charge shall consist of the base monthly charge for each unit plus a combined charge per 1,000 gallons consumed based on consumption, BOD, and TSS. The average consumption billed during the months of January, February, and March shall be used for computing the sewer service charge for the next 12 months. (g) Establishment of categories of industries and means of setting fees. Industries discharging less than 100,000 gallons per month may be grouped in categories according to SIC classification for the purpose of sampling and billing. A representative sample will be made of selected establishments within the category and an average sewage strength determined for that category. All establishments will then be billed for the amount of their discharge at the strengths determined for that category. (Code 1985, § 14-127; Ord. No. 05-111, § 2, 6-29-2005) Sec. 60-419. - Fees.
