DIVISION 2. - CONTROL OF BACKFLOW AND CROSS-CONNECTION
Sec. 60-486. - Purpose. (a) The purpose of this division is to protect the public potable water distribution system supplied by the water, gas and light commission (WGL) from the possibility of pollution or contamination by containing within its customers' internal or private water systems such pollutants or contaminants which could backflow into the public potable water system. (b) This division also provides for the maintenance of a continuing program for backflow prevention and cross-connection control, which will systematically and effectively prevent potential contamination or pollution of the public potable water distribution system and to provide penalties for the violation or noncompliance of the provisions of this division. (c) As drinking water quality standards are increasing in the state, a greater focus is now being given to the prevention of contamination of water distribution systems. Federal and state agencies have regulated cross-connection control and back-flow prevention for a long period of time. These regulations require the water purveyor to take measures to ensure compliance and assist in the protection of the water supply and public health. Sec. 60-487. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the vessel. An approved air-gap shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically, above the top of the overflow rim of the receiving vessel and in no case less than one inch. Approved means accepted by the WGL as meeting an applicable specification stated or citied in this division, or as suitable for the purposed use. Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the premises other than the purveyor's approved public potable water supply. These waters may be contaminated or polluted or they may be objectionable and constitute an unacceptable water source over which the water purveyor has no sanitary control. Backflow means the reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either backpressure or backsiphonage. Backflow assembly, backflow device, or backflow preventer means an approved device designed to prevent backflow. Approved devices shall be as follows: (1) Double check valve assembly means an assembly of two independently operating approved check valves with tightly closing shut-off valves on each end of the check valves, plus properly located test cocks for the testing of each check valve. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by a laboratory and field evaluation program resulting in an approval of a recognized and approved testing agency for backflow prevention assemblies (e.g., The University of Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research). To be approved, these devices must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. (2) Double check valve detector check assembly shall have the same requirements as a double check valve assembly, but shall be provided with a metered bypass to detect the flow of water through the assembly. (3) Reduced pressure principle assembly means an assembly of two independently acting approved check valves, together with a hydraulically operating mechanically independent pressure relief valve located between the check valves and at the same time below the first check valve. The unit shall include properly located test cocks and tightly closing shut-off valves at each end of the assembly. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by a laboratory and field evaluation program resulting in an approval of a recognized and approved testing agency for backflow prevention assemblies (e.g., The University of Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research). The assembly shall operate to maintain the pressure in the zone between the two check valves at an acceptable level less than the pressure on the public water supply of the device. At cessation of normal flow the pressure between the two check valves shall be less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the device. In case of leakage of either of the check valves, the differential relief valve shall operate to maintain the reduced pressure in the zone between the check valves by discharging to the atmosphere. When the inlet pressure is two pounds per square inch or less, the relief valve shall open to the atmosphere. To be approved, these devices must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance and be installed in a location where no part of the device will be submerged. (4) Reduced pressure principal detector check assembly shall have the same requirements as a reduced pressure principal assembly, but, shall be provided with a metered bypass to detect the flow of water through the assembly. Backpressure means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances under pressure into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than the intended source. Backsiphonage means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any other source other than its intended source caused by sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. Certified tester means a person who has met the requirements set forth by the state environmental protection division to test backflow prevention assemblies. Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease. Consumer, user, means anyone that uses the water provided and delivered by the WGL water distribution system. Cross-connection means any actual or potential connection, link, or structural arrangement between the public potable water supply distribution system and any other source or system through which it would be possible to introduce into any part of the public potable water supply system any used water, liquids, mixtures or substances. Cross-connection controlled means a connection between the public potable water distribution system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow prevention assembly properly installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford the protection required. Cross-connection controlled by containment means the installation of one approved backflow prevention assembly immediately downstream of the water meter, service connection or at the point where WGL loses sanitary control. Customer, user, means anyone who purchases the water provided and delivered by the WGL water distribution system. Fire line means a water service that provides water from the public water system for the purpose of supplying water for fire protection equipment (e.g., fire hydrants or fire sprinkler systems). General manager means the general manager of the board of water, gas and light commissioners of the city, who is vested with the authority and responsibility for the implementation of an effective cross-connection control program and for the enforcement of the provisions of this division. Hazard, degree of, shall be derived from an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the public potable water distribution system: (1) Hazard, health, means any condition, device or practice in the water supply system and it's operation which could create, or in the judgment of the WGL, may create a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. (2) Hazard, pollution, means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or to the portability of the public or the consumer's potable water system which would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but, would not be dangerous to the health or well-being of the consumer. Hotbox means a box or other similar device built specifically for the purpose of protecting a backflow prevention assembly from freezing and from environmental elements. Industrial fluids means any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, system pollution or plumbing hazard if introduced into the public potable water distribution system. Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance, organic, inorganic or biological, in water which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual hazard to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect such waters domestic use. Water meter means any device placed into service by WGL to determine the amount of water being used through the water service connection to a premises. Water, nonpotable, means water which is not safe for human consumption or is no longer under the sanitary of WGL. Water, potable, means any water which, according to recognized standards, is safe for human consumption and is under the sanitary control of WGL. Water purveyor means a supplier of water, i.e., WGL. Water service connection means the terminal end of a service connection from the public potable water distribution system, i.e., where the WGL loses jurisdiction and/or sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customer's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection means the downstream end of the meter. There should be no unprotected take-offs between the water meter and backflow prevention assembly located at the point of delivery to the customer's water system. Service connection shall also include water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency service connections from the public potable water distribution system. Water system means that system which is made up of two parts, the board of water, gas and light commissioners system and the customer's system, as follows: (1) The board of water, gas and light commissioners water system shall consist of the source facilities and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities of the water system under complete control of the water, gas and light commission, up to the point where the customer's system begins. (2) The source shall include all components of the facilities used in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of the water to the distribution system. (3) The distribution system shall include the network of conduits used for the delivery of water from the source to the customer's system. (4) The customer's system shall include those parts of the facilities beyond the termination of the WGL distribution system which are used in conveying WGL delivered domestic water to its point of use. Water, used, means any water supplied by WGL through the public potable water distribution system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the point of delivery and is no longer under the sanitary control of WGL. WGL means the water, gas and light commission. WGL representative means an employee of the water, gas and light commission of the city, that the general manager has delegated the authority and responsibility of implementing an effective cross-connection control program and for the enforcement of provisions of this division. Sec. 60-488. - Responsibility. The water, gas and light commission (WGL) shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or pollutants through the public potable water service connection. If the WGL requires, now or in the future, an approved backflow prevention assembly to protect its water distribution system, the WGL shall give notice, in writing, to the customer to install an approved backflow prevention assembly at each service connection to such customer's premises. The customer must take necessary arrangements to install or to have installed at his or her own expense, an approved backflow assembly immediately downstream of the water meter or water service connection. Failure, refusal or inability on the part of the customer to install, have tested and maintain such assembly shall constitute a grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such requirements have been satisfactorily met. Sec. 60-489. - Requirements. (a) No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained by the water purveyor unless the water supply is protected as required by federal and state laws and regulations and WGL's control of backflow and cross-connections ordinance. Service of water to any premises shall be discontinued by the water purveyor if a backflow prevention assembly required by this division is not installed, tested and maintained, at the customer's expense, or if it is found that a backflow prevention assembly has been removed or by-passed, or if an unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises. Service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected satisfactorily. (b) The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to authorized representatives of WGL to determine whether cross-connections or other sanitary hazards including violations of this ordinance exist. When such a condition becomes known, the WGL shall deny or immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing a physical break in the service line until the customer has corrected the conditions in compliance with federal, state and city statutes and regulations relating to plumbing and water supplies. (c) An approved backflow prevention assembly shall be installed, at the customer's expense, on each service line to the customer's water system immediately downstream of the water meter, service connection or at the point at which the WGL loses sanitary control. (d) It shall be the duty of the customer-user at any premise where backflow prevention devices are installed to have certified inspections and operational tests made at least once per year. In those instances where the WGL deems the hazard to be great enough, more frequent inspection intervals may be required. These inspections and tests shall be at the expense of the water user and shall be performed by a certified tester. It shall be the duty of the WGL to see that theses tests are done in a timely manner. The customer-user shall notify the WGL in advance when the tests are undertaken so that WGL representatives may witness the tests if so desired. These devices shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the customer-user whenever such devices are found to be defective. Records of such tests, repairs or replacements shall be kept and made available to the WGL. (e) It shall be the duty of the customer-user/property owner at any premise where backflow prevention assemblies are required to be installed above ground, to provide adequate freeze protection and protection from environmental elements, i.e., a hotbox. (f) Only those persons that possess a valid state plumbing license or utility contractors license or the property owner, may install a backflow prevention assembly. (g) Only those persons that possess a valid certification from a tester certification program recognized by the state environmental protection division and are approved by WGL shall test any backflow prevention assembly. (h) Only those persons that possess a valid state plumbers license or a valid backflow preventer repair certification and are approved by WGL, may repair any backflow prevention assembly. (i) Each backflow prevention assembly shall be tested immediately after installation, repair or relocation. (j) Gauges used in testing of backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested annually in accordance with the University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection or American Water Works Association Manual 14. Testers shall be required to include test gauge serial numbers and the due date for the next calibration when submitting backflow test reports. (k) The type of protective device required to be installed at the expense of the customer under subsection (c) of this section shall depend upon the degree of hazard which exists as follows: (1) At premises where there is an auxiliary water supply which is not or may not be of a safe bacteriological or chemical quality and which is not acceptable as an additional source by the WGL, or any premises where there may be water, substance or materials that could be hazardous to health or where there is an uncontrollable cross-connection, whether actual or potential, the public water system shall be protected by the installation of an approved reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly. (2) At premises where there may be water, substances or materials that may be objectionable but not considered a hazard to public health if introduced into the public water supply, the public water system shall be protected by an approved double check valve assembly. (3) At premises that have a fire line installed for fire protection, the public water system shall be protected by an approved double check valve detector assembly. If the fire line is fully metered, a double check valve assembly shall be installed. (4) At premises that have a fire line where antifreeze or any other chemicals are added to a fire sprinkler system, or where it is possible for the fire line to be connected to an auxiliary water source, the public water system shall be protected by a reduced pressure principal detector assembly. If the fire line is fully metered, a reduced pressure principal assembly shall be installed. (l) Any backflow prevention assembly required herein shall be a model and size approved by the WGL. The term "approved backflow prevention assembly or device," for the purpose of this section, means an assembly or device that has been manufactured in full conformance with the standards established by the American Water Works Association entitled: (1) AWWA C510-97, or latest revision (AWWA standard for double check valve backflow prevention assembly). (2) AWWA C511-97, or latest revision (AWWA standard for reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly). (m) All presently installed backflow prevention assemblies which do not meet the requirements of this division but were approved devices for the purposes described at the time of installation and which have been properly maintained, shall, except for the inspection and maintenance requirements, be excluded from the requirements of this division so long as the WGL is assured that the device will satisfactorily protect the distribution system. Whenever the device is moved from its present location or requires more than the minimum maintenance, the device shall be replaced by an approved backflow prevention assembly meeting the requirements of this division. Sec. 60-490. - General notification. The WGL shall provide general notification of the public through media advertising, bill inserts or similar means, and direct notification of this division's existence and purpose. Sec. 60-491. - Violations; penalties. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any requirement of this division or to violate any provision hereof. In addition to the general penalties mentioned in section 1-17, service shall be terminated if the violation or noncompliance is not promptly remedied. Secs. 60-492—60-877. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - POLES AND WIRES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to reasonably exercise police power over the erection and maintenance of poles, wires and other facilities of electric suppliers, O.C.G.A. § 46-3-14.
Sec. 60-878. - Under control of superintendent of light and power department. All poles, posts, cross-arms, wires and all electrical or other fixtures thereto appertaining, now placed, erected, owned or used, or which may hereafter be placed, erected, owned or used, under proper franchise or permission of the city, in or on any street, alley or public place in the city by any telegraph, telephone, electric light or power or street railway company, or any electrical construction or repair company, or any person, shall be under the control, direction and supervision of the superintendent of the light and power department. (Code 1975, § 21-1; Code 1985, § 27-111) Sec. 60-879. - Permit required for placing of poles, stringing of wires, etc. Before exercising any right or privilege under any franchise heretofore granted or that may be hereafter granted to any of the persons named in section 60-878 relative to the placing of poles or stringing wires or changing the location of poles, cross-arms, wires or other fixtures thereto appertaining, or before any repair is done to the same, such persons shall first obtain written permission from the superintendent of the light and power department to do the same, which written permission shall specify exactly what is to be done and shall be signed by the superintendent of the light and power department and approved by the general manager of the water, gas and light commission. (Code 1975, § 21-2; Code 1985, § 27-112) Sec. 60-880. - Record of permits; report. The superintendent of the light and power department shall keep a full and complete record of all permits issued under this article and when required, shall make a report thereof to the water, gas and light commission. (Code 1975, § 21-3; Code 1985, § 27-113) Secs. 60-881—60-908. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - EXCAVATIONS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— The Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 60-909. - Permit—Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation or opening in any street, alley or public highway of the city without first having obtained a permit from the director of engineering to do so. The city engineer shall coordinate with the water, gas and light commission prior to granting such permit. (Code 1975, § 29-101; Code 1985, § 24-101) Sec. 60-910. - Same—Application. Any person desiring a permit required by this article shall make application therefor, such application to contain the following information: (1) Lot number, block number, addition or subdivision of the town and street number, if any, if none, then such data as will designate the exact location where the excavation is to be made; (2) Dimensions of the proposed excavation; (3) Purpose for which excavation will be used; (4) What precautions will be used to protect children and adults from falling into it (i.e. barricade open excavations and post warning lights for safety of persons; operate warning lights as necessary depending on light conditions, but as a minimum from dusk to dawn each day); (5) Indicate on the permit drawings precautions that will be implemented to prevent the excavation from becoming flooded with water as well as to protect structures, utilities, sidewalks, pavements and other facilities immediately adjacent to excavations from damage caused by settlement, lateral movement, undermining, washout and other hazards; (6) In case of underground storage, the kind of substance to be stored, and the capacity of the storage that will be installed; (7) Indicate the date that the work will start. Applicant shall submit drawings for review a minimum of 14 days prior to commencing the work. Work shall not commence until applicant has received an approved permit. The permit shall be posted at the site; (8) Name and address of the owner; (9) Distance from, direction from and generally its location with reference to all nearby streets, alleys and public places and grounds (show location of proposed excavation in relationship to street or alley right-of-way or easement); (10) In the case of underground storage for gasoline, a volatile of any kind or an explosive of any kind, the application shall obligate the applicant to sink the storage container to such depth that the top of it will be at least three feet below the ground surface level, and that the space above the top of the container will be filled with three feet of firm dirt, gravel or other compact filler material and well tamped up to ground surface level. Applicant must obtain permitting from any other governing authorities having jurisdiction regarding underground storage tanks and comply with applicable requirements where such requirements exceed those specified in this section; (11) Applicant shall indicate on drawings any and all traffic control measures necessary which will minimize inconvenience to vehicular and pedestrian traffic. When flaggers are utilized, individuals must meet local and state requirements. Contractor shall provide documentation that flaggers are certified. When trenching activities cross a roadway, applicant shall provide plans indicating all traffic control measures to be implemented to maintain traffic on all roads and streets which must be crossed by the trenching activities and must make two separate cuts so that at least one traffic lane is open at all times. All traffic controls must conform to pt. VI of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, ANSI D6.1.e; (12) Indicate on plans the limits of side slopes of excavation to comply with subpt. P of pt. 1926 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) as amended. If space restrictions or material stability issues exist, indicate on the plans provided any shoring or bracing to be used; (13) Exceptions. In case of emergency, a utility company or the utility companies contractor may proceed with the work in accordance with applicable requirements of all governing agencies. The utility company or the utility's contractor will obtain a permit not later than one working day after the work has begun. (Code 1975, § 29-102; Code 1985, § 24-102) Sec. 60-911. - Same—Fee. Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant therefor shall pay a fee in an amount as has been established by the board of city commissioners. (Code 1975, § 29-103; Code 1985, § 24-103) Sec. 60-912. - Bond required. The director of engineering shall estimate the probable cost of replacing the soil which may be removed from such public street or highway; and shall require the applicant to file a written bond in an amount sufficient to cover such cost, with two or more sufficient sureties, conditioned that the street shall be restored in as good condition as it was before the excavation or opening therein was made. Such bond shall be received and approved by the director of engineering. If the applicant elects to do so, the applicant may make a cash deposit in lieu of the written bond. The amount of the bond or cash deposit shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of city commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1975, § 29-104; Code 1985, § 24-104) Sec. 60-913. - Issuance of permit. (a) When the bond or deposit required in this article shall have been accepted by the director of engineering, the director of engineering shall then issue a permit for the excavation or opening named in the application, and the applicant may then proceed with the work in the exact location named in such applicant's application, and in no other place. (b) A permit issued pursuant to law authorizing excavation operations shall not be deemed to relieve a person from responsibility for complying with the provisions of sections 54-53 through 60-955 and the Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act (O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq.). (Code 1975, § 29-105; Code 1985, § 24-105; Ord. No. 87-210, § 3, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-914. - Records of applications for permits. The director of engineering shall keep an accurate record of all applications for permits under this article and the disposition made thereof. (Code 1975, § 29-106; Code 1985, § 24-106) Sec. 60-915. - Expiration of permits. All permits issued under this article will expire at the end of 60 days from issuance if the work shall not have been started by then. (Code 1975, § 29-107; Code 1985, § 24-107) Sec. 60-916. - Authority of director of engineering. The director of engineering shall have the authority to prescribe working rules and regulations governing work performed under the provisions of this article in order to insure traffic flow. (Code 1975, § 29-109; Code 1985, § 24-109) Sec. 60-917. - Protection of public. It shall be the duty of any person making any excavation in the streets of the city to adequately and sufficiently protect all such excavations by barricades or other obstructions, including not less than one red light on each side of such excavation during the nighttime, so as to prevent accidents or injury to persons or property until such time as the excavation is resurfaced and approved by the director of engineering. (Code 1975, § 29-110; Code 1985, § 24-110) Sec. 60-918. - Supervision of work. All the work of excavating or making any character of opening in any of the streets, alleys or highways of the city shall at all times be under the supervision of the director of engineering; and the person doing such work shall do the same in the manner directed by the director of engineering to the end that the streets and highways of the city shall not be unduly disturbed and traffic thereon obstructed. (Code 1975, § 29-111; Code 1985, § 24-111) Sec. 60-919. - Duties upon completion of work. After the excavation or opening shall have been made, the person so making it shall backfill the excavation with such materials and in such manner as the director of engineering may require, and leave the street or highway in at least the same condition as it was before the opening therein was made. (Code 1975, § 29-112; Code 1985, § 24-112) Sec. 60-920. - Acceptance, inspection of completed work. The conditions of the bond required by this article shall not be considered to have been complied with until the director of engineering shall have accepted the street or highway as being in good condition. In the event that the person making the opening shall fail to leave the highway in a good state of repair, satisfactory to the director of engineering, then the director of engineering shall call upon the bondsmen to pay for the cost of repairing such highway; provided, however, that if a cash deposit was given instead of a bond, the director of engineering may proceed to have the street or other highway put in good condition, paying for the same out of the deposit made with the director of engineering, and if there is any remainder of the deposit after paying for such work, such remainder shall be refunded to the person making the deposit. (Code 1975, § 29-113; Code 1985, § 24-113) Secs. 60-921—60-945. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - AVOIDANCE OF UNDERGROUND UTILITY FACILITIES
Sec. 60-946. - Statement of purpose. (a) Excavation or demolition operations that are performed without knowledge of the presence or location of underground utility facilities, or without reasonable precaution when such presence of location is known, has and continues to be a cause of damage to such facilities which can result in loss of life, health and property. (b) The purpose of this division is, among other things, to provide procedures designed to insure that persons performing excavation or demolition operations know, prior to commencing such operations, of the presence and location of underground utility facilities in the excavation or demolition area. (c) This division also provides that certain precautions shall be taken to avoid damage to underground utility facilities during excavation and demolition operations, for notices to affected parties when underground utility facilities are damaged, and for penalties for violations of the division. (Code 1985, § 24-121; Ord. No. 87-210, § 1, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-947. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Underground utility facility includes all electrical, water, fiber optic, and/or gas lines owned by water, gas and light commission of the city, as well as sanitary and storm sewers owned by the city; whether located within or without the corporate limits of the city. WGL means water, gas and light commission of the city. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this article, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3. (Code 1985, § 24-122; Ord. No. 87-210, § 2, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-948. - Participation in utilities protection center. The water, gas and light commission and the city will at all times maintain its membership and participation in the Utilities Protection Center, which is a "one-call notification center" organized under and pursuant to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq., as amended, and shall otherwise comply with the requirements of said chapter 9, as amended from time to time. (Code 1985, § 24-123; Ord. No. 87-210, § 4, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-949. - Response to notice of intent to excavate. Where notified in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq., the WGL and the city shall, in addition to the duties imposed upon it by said chapter 9, furnish the following information and assistance to the person responsible for the excavation: (1) Furnish, in addition to the information required by O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq., any other information which would assist that person in locating and thereby avoiding damage to the underground utility facilities in locations where permanent markers do not exist. For purposes of this section the approximate location of underground utility facilities is defined as a strip of land at least four feet wide, but not wider than the width of the utility facility plus two feet on either side thereof. (2) Whenever the city and/or the WGL determines that the work may be done only in the presence of city personnel and WGL personnel, the city and WGL shall so notify the excavator, and it shall be unlawful for the excavator receiving such notification to perform any work unless city personnel and WGL personnel are present. (3) No excavation operation shall be commenced or continued until the provisions of this section and of this division have been complied with. (Code 1985, § 24-124; Ord. No. 87-210, § 5, 12-8-1987; Ord. No. 09-141, § 11, 12-15-2009) Sec. 60-950. - Precautions to avoid damages. Each person responsible for any excavation activity shall: (1) Plan the excavation to avoid damage to and minimize interference with underground utility facilities in and near the construction area. (2) Maintain such a clearance between an underground utility facility and the cutting edge or point of any mechanized equipment that, taking into account the known limit of control of such cutting edge or point, may be reasonably necessary to avoid damage to such facility. (3) Provide such support for underground utility facilities in and near the construction area, including during backfill operations, as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of such facilities. (4) Prior to construction of underground facilities, proposed locations shall be marked with white flags and white paint before all other existing underground utilities have been marked in the work area covered by the proposed construction. (Code 1985, § 24-125; Ord. No. 87-210, § 6, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-951. - Excavation damage. (a) Except as provided by subsection (b) of this section, each person responsible for any excavation activity that results in any damage to an underground utility facility shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the city and WGL of the location and nature of the damage and shall allow the city and WGL reasonable time to accomplish necessary repairs before completing the excavation in the immediate area of such utility. (b) Each person responsible for any excavation activity that results in damage to an underground utility facility permitting the escape of any flammable, toxic or corrosive gas or liquid shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the city and/or WGL and take any other action that may be reasonably necessary to protect persons and property and to minimize the hazards until arrival of the city personnel and/or WGL personnel or police and fire departments. (Code 1985, § 24-126; Ord. No. 87-210, § 7, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-952. - List of excavators. The city and WGL shall prepare and maintain, on a current basis, a list of persons who normally engage in excavation activities in the area in which underground utility facilities are located. (Code 1985, § 24-127; Ord. No. 87-210, § 8, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-953. - General notification. The city and WGL shall provide general notification to the public through media advertising, bill inserts, or similar means, and direct notification to the list of excavators identified in section 60-952 of the program's existence and purpose, and how to learn the location of underground utility facilities before the excavation activities begin. (Code 1985, § 24-128; Ord. No. 87-210, § 9, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-954. - Inspections. The city and WGL shall conduct regular inspections during and after the activities as frequently as may be necessary to verify the integrity of the utility facility. In the case of blasting, such inspections shall include leakage surveys. (Code 1985, § 24-129; Ord. No. 87-210, § 10, 12-8-1987) Sec. 60-955. - Penalties. The failure to comply with the requirements of section 60-949(2) and (3), or with any of the requirements of sections 60-950 and 60-951, shall be an offense punishable under section 1-17. Each day any such failure or violation continues shall constitute a separate punishable offense. (Code 1985, § 24-130; Ord. No. 87-210, § 11, 12-8-1987)

div.head: Chapter 62 - VEGETATION[1]
div.p:
